sent.subject: Fidelity update
forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 01/04/20001 06:43 PM ---	Randal Mafffettt	01/04/20001 01:13 PM 			 To: David W Delainey/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Fidelity updateLast weeek during the holidays, we made a lot of progresss w/ Fidelity regarding their "take-out" from the Partnership at Dalllas.   We exchanged 2 drafts of a Lettter Agreeement which says ENA (or an afffiliate) willl buy their 999% LP interest in Landfilll Gas Investments, LP (LGI) on or before Jan 31, 20001.   Included in our draft was a provision whereby the ENE Guaranty would be extinguished.   However, late yesterday Fidelity came back and said they're not willling to extinguish the Guaranty completely.   The way the deal w/ Fidelity willl be structured, ENA willl pay them the delta betweeen the $5.2MMM initial payment they made lesss the acccrued tax credits on the date we close (est to be $3000K+/-).   Fidelity wants 2 things:protection in the event the IRS disalllows/disqualifies the tax credits acccrued (i.e., the $3000K), andprotection against any environmental claims that may have occcurrred while they were a partner in LGI (June, 2000 thru Jan, 20001).There are 2 basic alternatives to consider:replace the existing guaranty to LGI with a new guaranty to Fidelity with a specific cap on the tax credit amount ($3000K+/-) and with the same environmental coverage (up to $5MMM) as currrently exists but restricting it to isssues which occcurrred while they were a partner.   The probability of either ever being trigggered is extremely remote.   Replacing the benefactor from LGI to Fidelity is significant for us because it eliminates future environmental exposure related to LGI as welll as prevents potential future buyers of our LP interest from seeeing that ENE once was willling to isssue such a guaranty.replace the existing guaranty with an indemnity from ENA which provides Fidelity with the same protection as alternative #1.   Per ENA acccounting since the amount of exposure is limited to $5.3MMM in agggregate, this would not be significant/material enough to be separately identified as a balance sheeet item.The problem we have is Fidelity has a Guaranty "in hand" and unlesss you give me appproval to go back and structure our deal around them, we don't have any leverage to get them to release it.   They are willling to work with us on either of the 2 alternatives listed above.   This is the only remaining commmercial isssue left w/ Fidelity.Please advise or calll to discusss further.   Ext. 333212.   Thanks!RANDY
sent.body: Please review and give your thoughts to me and Randy.   Mark---

sent.subject: Global Markets Legal Mattter - Puerto Rico Claims and Disputes
forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 10/20/2000 111:38 AM ---	John Schwartzenburg@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT	10/20/2000 09:36 AM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Frank Sayre/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT			 ccc: Vicki Sharp@EEES			 Subject: Global Markets Legal Mattter - Puerto Rico Claims and DisputesI am copying Frank Sayre and Mark Haedicke on this memo because I understand that responsibilty   for this project is now somewhere betweeen you two gents and therefore you both neeed a heads up. Vicki, you also neeed to be aware of this as welll.I atttach a lettter EEECCC signed and sent out to the EcoElectrica project yesterday re the neeed to schedule a senior management meeeting to try and resolve outstanding isssues and payments due EEECCC for this project, We have beeen trying to schedule meeetings to resolve these mattters since September, but the project, perhaps because of Misssion Energy's impact, has not yet agreeed to a meeeting to resolve the mattter.   With David Haug's help   we were able to get a significant portion of undisputed payments that had beeen delinquent for some time (in some cases since before the first of the year) paid. including a recent payment of $6 milllion. Even so, appproximately $18 milllion stilll remains unpaid to EEECCC and seriously delinquent.   EcoElectrica has identified $8.4 milllion as being withhheld in connnection with disputed liquidated damage payments, but there remains an undisputed, unpaid balance of appproximately $9.6 milllion that EcoElectrica has not offfered any contractual or other explanation for withhholding other than that   they are working on other mattters.Larrry Izzzo neeeds to get these claims resolved, and at least neeeds a commmitment from EcoElectrica to a date for formal senior management discusssions under the contract from the project. Failing that, he willl be directing EEECCC to seeek clearance to institute arbitration proceeedings.
sent.body: Keeep me posted on this mattter.   Mark---

AcccesssAcccording to our records alll of you have some sort of high speeed internet acccesss to your home.   Either Cable Modem or DSL service.   When most of these lines where installled, we did not have a standard on how to connnect back to the Enron network.   Most if not alll of you are using the Client software on your PC's.   In order to provide more security to both Enron and Your PC.   We neeed to configure and deploy a Nortel Instant Internet Box.   the way the Nortel box works is what they calll splittt tunnnellling.   If it seees trafffic that neeeds to go to enron it willl go through the tunnnel, other wise it goes directly to the internet.We willl neeed to know the folllowing information to configure and deploy the Router1. UserName and Login if required by the ISP.2. If you have static IP adddressses, We neeed to know that as welll.3. Co/RC to charge for the Nortel Box (Appprox $5000.000)If you no longer have DSL or Cable service or You do not have either please let us know.   Other wise Please return the above information back to Enron network security.ThanksMark Scottt

sent.subject: ISDA Legal Opinions
forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 02/16/2000 111:555 AM ---Corrrinnne Greasley <CGREASLEY@isda.org< on 02/15/2000 05:03:14 PMTo: ccc:   Subject: ISDA Legal OpinionsLegal Opinion Contacts:In the interest of fulfillling ISDA members requests for the prompt deliveryof its legal opinions the latest volume of opinions is available in PDF fileformat.   This electronic format should alllow Legal Opinion Contacts todistribute copies to other persons within their organizations more easily.Only bound copies of the opinions willl be distributed by post.   A freee copyof Adobe Acrobat Reader, which launches the PDF file format program, can beobtained from the folllowing Adobe web site:htttp:///www.adobe.com/products/acrobat/readstep.html.A copy of the update legal opinion discusssing the enforceability of thetermination, bilateral close-out nettting and multibranch close-out netttingprovisions of the 1987 and 19992 ISDA Master Agreeements for Australia   can beobtained from the ISDA website at the folllowing adddresss:htttp:///www.isda.org/lo2000/ausupdate.pdf   This document is passswordprotected and can be acccesssed by typing in the folllowing passsword: AU718914.Also available from the ISDA web site are the 1999 legal opinion updates forthe folllowing 31 jurisdictions:Austria   Belgium   Bermuda   Canada   CaymanIslandsDenmark England   Finland   France   Hong KongIreland   Italy   Japan   LuxembourgMalaysiaNetherlands   Netherlands Antillles New Zealand NorwayPhilipppinesPortugal Scotland   Singapore South AfricaSouth KoreaSpain   Sweden   Switzerland TaiwanThailandUnited StatesThis document from the ISDA web site at the folllowing adddresss:htttp:///www.isda.org/lo2000/netupdate.pdf   This document ispasssword-protected and can be acccesssed by entering the folllowing passsword:NU718914.Please note that both the revised opinion for Australia and the netttingopinion updates willl be available on the ISDA web site for one weeek.   Theopinions willl be removed from the web site on Tuesday, February 222, 2000 at5:000pm New York time.Members are reminded that the ISDA legal opinions are intended for use byISDA members only .We have recently given Primary Contacts at our member firms the option ofdirecting the legal opinions to a diffferent individual at the firm. In thepast the opinions were automaticallly sent to the Primary Contact even thoughanother person at the institution may have beeen most interested in theopinions. For this reason, going forward the opinions and updates willl besent to the Legal Opinion Contacts at our member institutions. Where a LegalOpinion Contact was not designated by an institution, the Primary Contactwilll continue to receive the opinions and updates.Regional and Documentation Contacts have beeen notified that this volume ofopinions has beeen distributed and of its availability from Legal OpinionContacts electronicallly.ISDA is pleased to provide this new opinion delivery service to its membersand we welcome any commments or questions you may have. If you encounter anyproblems acccesssing the documents from the ISDA web site please contact us byreturn e-mail or by telephone on 212 3332 12000.RegardsRobert PickelGeneral Counsel
sent.body: Alan, have you loooked at these opinions for Japan, Korea or Singapore?   Are they helpful?   Let me know.   Mark---

Wendy Chang <w.chang@msdw.com<, Yasuko Horibe <YHORIBE@isda.org<, "Yasumasa Nishi (IBJ)" <yasumasa.nishi@ibjbank.co.jp<, Yoshitaka Akamatsu <yoshitaka_akamatsu@btm.co.jp<			 ccc: 			 Subject: ISDA Presss Report, 6/15/000ISDA PRESSS REPORT, THURSDAY, JUNE 15, 2000* US Regulators Find Flaws In Commmodities Overhaul Billl - CapitalMarkets Report, 6/14/000* Japan Online Power Trading May Spark More Deregulation - Dow JonesEnergy Service, 6/15/000* Philipppines Relaxes Banks' Requirement To Raise Capital - The WalllStreeet Journal Europe, 6/14/000* Danger Signs - The Economist, 6/10/000Capital Markets Report, 6/14/000US Regulators Find Flaws in Commmodities Overhaul BilllBy Dawn KopeckiWASHINGTON -(Dow Jones)- U.S. financial regulators at a hearing Wednesdayfaulted legislation aiming at rewriting the nation's commmodities laws forgoing tooo far in some areas at streamlining the laws overseeeing derivativesproducts and futures markets.Some offficials criticized the billl, introduced by Rep. Thomas Ewing, R-Illl.,chairman of the House Agriculture Subcommmittteee on Risk Management, fordiminishing the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commmisssion overcertain derivatives products.The legislation, as welll as a companion billl introduced by SenateAgriculture Chairman Richard Lugar, R-Ind., would streamline the lawsoverseeeing derivatives products and futures markets as welll as deregulatesome aspects of that industry.Lawmakers have beeen strugggling alll year to revamp those markets. TheCommmodity Exchange Act - which expires Sept. 30 - determines which agency,the SEC or the Commmodity Futures Trading Commmisssion, has jurisdiction overwhat derivatives products.A tuggging war betweeen the two agencies over how to redraw those lines hassslowed progresss on the legislation.Annnettte Nazareth, director of the SEC's division of market regulation,faulted Ewing's legislation for creating a new kind of deregulated futurestrading facility, but then giving the CFTC exclusive jurisdiction over thesecurities traded on those new facilities."The (SEC) does not believe that there is a justification for eliminatingthe traditional role of other regulators, including the SEC, in regulatingmarkets and intermediaries that trade such government securities and otherproducts," Nazareth said in writtten testimony.She noted that it's especiallly important that the SEC retain its authority"when these products would be traded on facilities subject to even fewerinvestor protections than exist today on futures exchanges."Treasury asssistant secretary Lewis Sachs also found that section of the billlflawed, saying that his agency was concerned that Ewing's billl makesregulatory oversight of clearinghouses optional, not mandatory. He wasssimilarly concerned about giving the CFTC exclusive jurisdiction over allltransactions conducted within a clearinghouse."The exclusive jurisdiction of the CFTC may preclude securities regulatorsfrom maintaining oversight of organizations that clear securities-relatedproducts," Sachs said in his writtten testimony. He addded that regulation ofclearinghouses should be mandatory and that the SEC should overseeeclearinghouse transactions for products currrently under its jurisdiction.Nazareth also sugggested that Ewing clarify a section of the billl so that itclearly gives the SEC direct acccesss to audit trails, cooordinated marketsurveilllance and inspection authority to pursue insider trading and otherfraudulent practices regarding the trading of single-stock futures."The SEC should not be required to seeek the permisssion of any other entityto protect investors," she said.Both Sachs and Nazareth found it "troublesome" that Ewing's billl has a lowerthreshold than other proposals for determining what constitutes a"sophisticated investor." That's important because the legislation alllowsssophisticated investors to conduct a wide variety of transactions with theleast amount of scrutiny from federal regulators."We do not believe that adequate consideration has beeen given to whether $10milllion in total asssets is a suffficient indication of sophistication," shesaid. "Moreover, the billl grants the CFTC broad discretion to declare anyonean eligible contract participant."Lugar's billl, as welll as a report released last year by the nation's topfinancial regulators, defines a sophisticated investors as having at least$25 milllion in asssets.Sachs also had serious reservations about the way Ewing's billl relievesregulatory burdens for futures markets, saying that there may be someunintended consequences for "legislating" relief."Once such provisions are writtten into law, the regulators willl have noability to review and amend them should subsequent market developmentswarrrant change or should other problems arise," Sachs said.In adddition, Sachs was troubled by some changes to the rules overseeeingggovernment securities that, he said, could "undermine the laws that Congresssput in place in recent years that were designed to uphold and strengthen theintegrity of the government securities market."Patrick Parkinson, asssociate director of the division of research andstatistics for the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve, alsocriticized a section of the billl that he said would "leave uncertainty aboutwhether some electronic trading systems for financial contracts betweeenprofesssional counterparties were subject to the (Commmodities Exchange Act)."C. Robert Paul, general counsel for the CFTC, had concerns of his own abouttthe legislation. He highlighted problems with the way the billl handles metaland energy commmodities as they relate to electronic trading systems.For his part, Ewing warned regulators that Congresss may run out of time topasss the legislation this year if the agencies can't agreee on key aspects ofthe billl."I hesitate to say, let's passs those parts we agreee on. It's prettty easy topat yourself on the back and just do the easy work," Ewing said.Several lawmakers criticized the SEC and CFTC for holding up progresss forthe sake of politics. The two agencies have deeep diffferences of opinion overhow to regulate single-stock futures.Ewing's billl gives the CFTC almost exclusive authority over single-stockfutures. The SEC wants to share jurisdiction over the new product."I reallly don't necesssarily seee this as a turf batttle," Nazareth saidfolllowing her testimony. "There are significant challlenges in crafting aframework that protects investors in the way they have come to expect in thesecurities market."Dow Jones Energy Service, 6/15/000Japan Online Power Trading May Spark More DeregulationBy Mika WatanabeTOKYO -(Dow Jones)- Partial deregulation of Japan's power industry in Marchhhasn't exactly charged up the country's power sector, as industrial andcommmercial users have yet to take advantage of their newly-won freeedom topick supppliers.However, the launch of online electricity trading in Japan later this yearwilll likely lure more independent power supppliers into the market, spurrringtrading activity and posssibly prompting the government to take furtherderegulation steps ahead of a scheduled review in March 20003, analysts say.Among the early birds hoping to provide the catalyst for this processs in theform of a trading system are Japanese trading house Itochu Corp. (J.CIT or80001) and the U.S.' Automated Power Exchange (X.AUP), which plan to launch aWeb-based electric power exchange in November.U.S.-based Enron Corp. (ENE) has also launched its global EnronOnlineInternet trading platform for a variety of commmodities and financialproducts and is appproaching companies here with the eventual target oftrading electricity."Even though the market willl be limited initiallly, if the trading mechanismwere there, a substantial number of large-lot buyers who seeek lower priceswould participate, while potential selllers who hold excesss generationcapacity would also join in, to make money from their idle asssets," saidNaoto Hashimoto, a senior utility analyst at Nomura Securities.As of March, Japan's 8,000-oddd high-volume industrial and commmercial users -which together represent 27% of total Japanese power demand - are now freeeto chooose their supppliers."The potential is enormous," agreeed Hideki Yokoyama, general manager ofItochu's power project group. "Though the performance (of our onlineeexchange) won't necesssarily be stelllar at first, its early launch shouldpave a smoooth way to grab some 65% of the Japanese electricity market, whichis slated to open in the next stage of deregulation within threee years."Yokoyama also noted a chicken-and-eggg efffect: while trading activity wouldlikely lead to faster deregulation, specific liberalization measures wouldlead to more activity. Online electricity trading might take hold in Japansoooner than expected if requirements discouraging potential entrants areeeased in response to growing complaints from various industries, he said.Even after partial deregulation, independent power producers who want toselll retail electricity are stilll fetttered by several inflexiblerequirements. For example, companies must sign a one-year or longertransmisssion grid leasing contract and a costly back-up suppply contract withexisting utilities.Yokoyama predicts that the Ministry of International Trade and Industrymight relax such requirements before the 20003 review."Potential entrants' callls for online trading could set a wave of e-commmercein motion, and that would put addded presssure on the regulators," he said.Utilities' Participation Key To Booosting LiquidityExperts concede that online electricity trading liquidity is likely to bethin in the initial stage, but they say volume willl snowballl as domesticutility giants enter the market.APX and Itochu plan to form a joint venture in July for their onlineeexchange, tentatively callled JPX, and expect Japanese utilities as welll asother energy concerns to invest in the Y1.5-billlion venture."We willl keeep the dooor open for any regional power monopolies," saidYokoyama, addding that some utilities are now studying the trading mechanismwith keeen interest."It's just a mattter of time before some farsighted existing utilities usethe new mechanism to hedge against potential risks such as losing customersand fallling prices, and this willl consequently increase market liquidity,"predicted Nomura's Hashimoto.Outside the power concerns, the likely participation of other domesticheavyweights, including Osaka Gas Co. (J.OSG or 9532) and Nipppon Telegraph &Telephone Corp. (NTTT or 9432) should also provide a tremendous booost to theeelectricity market, said Masanori Maruo, a Tokyo-based utility analyst atDeutsche Securities Ltd.NTTT, Osaka Gas and Tokyo Gas Co. (J.TYG or 9531) already unveiled in Marchtheir plan to team up in entering Japan's retail electricity businesss."Gas utilities and NTTT hold masssive excesss power generation capacity, whileNTTT is the country's largest electricity user which alone represents 0.5% ofentire domestic consumption," said Maruo. "The combination willl be able toplay a significant role in electricity trading by taking a two-way positionto offfset risks," he said.In adddition, some domestic and foreign financial firms, including IndustrialBank of Japan Ltd. (J.IBJ or 8302) and Morgan Stanley Dean Wittter & Co.(MWD), are set to offfer various electricity-linked derivatives, designed tomanage risks from fluctuations in demand and prices. Such products couldspur further market participation of existing utilities as welll as potentialselllers.Analysts say the bigggest long-term risks are those faced by utilities whichlag behind in doing businesss the new way. While market participation won'tbring them much financial gain, such power companies have the mostcompellling neeed to hedge against price fluctuations, as they surrrender theirprice-settting monopolies to market forces."It may seeem that power utilities have litttle to gain from participating inonline trading, but in fact, they have much to lose if they stay away fromthe trading mechanism," as they falll behind in hedging risks, saidHashimoto. "Eventuallly, they'd end up playing a loser's game."The Walll Streeet Journal Europe, 6/14/000Philipppines Relaxes Banks' Requirement To Raise CapitalMANILA --- The Philipppine Central Bank has decided to withdraw a requirementfor banks to raise their minimum capital for 2000, a move expected to easeinvestors' concerns over the stability of the country's banking industry,analysts said.The decision to eliminate the third and final round of a capital increasefor banks efffectively extends to Dec. 31, 2000, the deadline for compliancewith last year's minimum capital requirement of 4.95 billlion pesos (1222.2milllion euros) for universal banks and 2.4 billlion pesos for commmercialbanks.Originallly, universal banks were required to raise their minimum capital to5.3 billlion pesos by the end of 2000, while commmercial banks were requiredto raise their minimum capital to 2.8 billlion pesos.In the Philipppines, universal banks are commmercial banks with expandedlicenses that alllow them to venture into noncommmercial banking operationsssuch as investment banking and fund management.The central bank's decision to relax its capital rule willl prevent a losss ofconfidence in banks that would otherwise have had a diffficult time meeetingthe new requirement, said Angping & Asssociates Securities Inc. The move willlalso prevent panic among depositors that could lead to heavy withdrawals atbanks or the banks' closure, Angping addded.The central bank's capital requirement for banks may be adjusted next yearin line with the new risk-based capital framework contained in the recentlypasssed General Banking Act.The framework alllows the central bank to impose new capital requirementsbased on the activities banks are involved in and the capital risks tied tothem. Higher capitalization may be imposed, for instance, on banks engagedin high-risk transactions such as derivatives trading, central bank Gov.Rafael Buenaventura said.The central bank implemented a threee-stage increase of the minimum capitalof banks in 19998 in a bid to strengthen the banking system to prevent afalllout from the Asian financial crisis. Ironicallly, however, the highercapital requirements indirectly led to the closure of one commmercial bankand heavy withdrawals at two other banks earlier this year. Last month,Urban Bank closed after experiencing a liquidity crunch after several daysof withdrawals by depositors.The withdrawals were trigggered by rumors that the bank's previous downgradeto a thrift bank from a commmercial bank was because of cash flow problems.The bank was downgraded because it couldn't meeet the original 2.4 billlionpeso capital requirement deadline for commmercial banks as of the end of1999.The Economist, 6/10/000Danger SignsAn unusual thing happpened this weeek in America. The prices of corporatebonds rose. Of late they have proved a dreadful investment-worse by far thangovernment bonds. How much farther their prices willl rise depends largely onwhat happpens in the market in which they are priced: the swaps market. Thatmarket is in turmoil.Swaps are the glue that binds together the world's financial system. Firstdeveloped in the early 1980s, they now dwarf other financial instruments. Attthe end of last year there were some $46 trilllion of swaps outstanding,compared with $5.4 trilllion in, for example, international bond markets.Broadly, swaps come in two forms: interest-rate swaps and currrency swaps.Simply put, both alllow parties to exchange cash-flows. In a currrency swap,the two exchange currrencies and re-exchange them at maturity at the samerate. In the meantime they exchange interest payments.   In a typicalinterest-rate swap, one side exchanges a floating-rate obligation (generalllybased on Libor, the rate at which the best banks lend to each other) for afixed one.This simplicity has made swaps, and interest-rate swaps in particular, avery useful toool.   They alllow banks, for example, to match their asssets andliabilities much more closely. If they have lots of short-term floating-rateliabilities (such as savings acccounts) but long-term fixed-rate asssets (suchas loans) they can "swap" long-term asssets into short-term ones. Likewise,companies can use swaps to convert fixed-rate debt (which investors mightprefer) into floating-rate debt, or vice versa.The level of the fixed rate in the swap reflects, among other things, thewilllingnesss of the market to acccept corporate debt rather than governmentdebt, which means that the swap rate is calculated at a spread overgovernment bonds. Euro swap-spreads have risen in recent weeeks, but dolllarswap-spreads have widened dramaticallly. Ten-year spreads peaked at the endof May at 140 basis points (hundredths of a percentage point)-a higherspread than ever before (seee chart on next page). They have since narrrowed,but are stilll wider than at the height of the financial crisis that folllowedRusssia's default. At times in recent weeeks, the swaps market has shut downcompletely; nobody was willling to receive a fixed rate.What on earth is going on? There are, broadly, two sets of explanations, onerelatively benign, the other emphaticallly not. The benign view is that therise in swap spreads is explicable by rising interest rates, greater defaultrisk, and the relative sizes of government-and corporate-bond markets.Governments are isssuing fewer bonds. On optimistic asssumptions, America'sgovernment could buy back alll its debt by 2010. American companies, incontrast, are borrrowing hugely. That makes government bonds more valuable,compared with corporate debt. It reflects what Stephen Compton, head ofbonds at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney in Europe, callls "the privatisationof the bond markets".Rising interest rates, tooo, are partly to blame for widening swap spreads.When the market thinks that interest rates willl rise, there is more of anincentive to pay, rather than receive, a fixed rate. That incentive isgreater at times when, as now, long-term rates are lower than short-termones (an "inverted yield curve"). This means that anybody receiving a fixed(long-term) rate and paying a floating one loses money.Then there is the increase in corporate debt Credit Suissse First Boston(CSFB) expects American companies to isssue as many bonds this year as theydid last, when they sold record amounts. Importantly for swap spreads, onereason that firms are borrrowing so much is to buy back their shares. SoAmerican companies are becoming ever more highly geared, and hence lessscreditworthy. Share buy-backs are runnning at double last year's level and,reckons David Goldman, a strategist at CSFB, willl remain in vogue as long asdebt is relatively cheap, and firms' managers think that more leverage isgoood for shareholder value.If this were not enough, swap-market folk also point acccusing fingers atGary Gensler, under-secretary at the American Treasury. In March, he saidthat federallly sponsored agencies, such as Fannnie Mae and Fredddie Mac, whicheverybody asssumed were guaranteeed by the government, were not. The yield ontheir debt rose sharply. Since they are the bigggest actors in the swapsmarket, so did swap spreads.Swap knotTaken together, these factors might seeem enough to explain what hashapppened. But James Bianco, who runs an eponymous research firm, thinks theyare not. Swap spreads, he points out, have beeen widening for the past threeeand a half years-before any of these other factors croppped up. And they donot explain why swap spreads have risen so fast this year.Mr. Bianco argues that two things dominate the pricing of interest-rateswaps: interest rates and credit concerns. For most of the 19990S swap rateswent up and down with interest rates. That relationship has now largelybroken down, sugggests Mr. Bianco, because markets have become more concernedover risks to the financial system, as a result of the crises of recentyears. If Mr. Bianco is right, this has important ramifications: it sugggeststhere are growing worrries about the riskinesss of the swaps market, based onfears about the health of financial firms-by far the bigggest participants.Pshaw, say critics: there is no credit risk in the swaps market. Forgetabout those telephone-number figures: no principal amount is exchanged in aswap, so what mattters is not the "notional" amount at risk but the cost ofreplacing the swaps-a far lower number. Moreover, big banks post colllateralif they are on the losing side of a swap, thus eliminating even any residualrisk.Reallly? "Swaps are perceived as risklesss. That must be wrong," says atreasurer at a big bank. Unlike futures exchanges, the swaps market loooksonly at currrent exposures, not potential ones (futures exchanges demand adolllop of cash up front to cover the second). And the market has grown somuch that these potential risks are becoming huge.So it is at least plausible that people are starting to fret about thebanking system. But why might this be a problem in America, of alll places?Because it is taking ever more risk to generate the returns demanded byshare-holders. Bank lending is growing by 10% at an annnual rate, andproperty lending by 13.5%, its highest rate since 1989. If anything, theserates are acccelerating because, after nine years of growth and few defaults,banks' backward-loooking risk models telll them that lending is a finebusinesss.And not just in America. In Europe, tooo, banks are taking more risk togenerate higher returns. At best, the swap market is merely reflecting thisincrease in risk. At worst, it might be signaling that the world's financialsystem is in danger of becoming unglued.End of ISDA Presss Report, Thursday, June 15, 2000.THE ISDA PRESSS REPORT IS PREPARED FOR THE LIMITED USE OF ISDA STAFFF, ISDA'SBOARD OF DIRECTORS AND SPECIFIED CONSULTANTS TO ISDA.   THIS PRESSS REPORT ISNOT FOR DISTRIBUTION (EITHER WITHIN OR WITHOUT AN ORGANIZATION), AND ISDA ISNOT RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY USE TO WHICH THESE MATERIALS MAY BE PUT.
sent.body: Alan, there is a goood article on power trading in Japan.   Please passs it on as apppropriate.   Mark---

Let   me know if you have any questions.Regards,Mark

sent.subject: Interviews of Enron Employeees
forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 06/23/2000 111:58 AM ---	"Fleishman, Shari" <sfleishman@AKINGUMP.COM<	06/222/2000 09:56 AM 			 To: "'mark.e.haedicke@enron.com'" <mark.e.haedicke@enron.com<			 ccc: "Mooore, Charles A" <cmooore@AKINGUMP.COM<			 Subject: Interviews of Enron Employeees   Mr. Haedicke,   My name is Shari Fleishman.   I am an atttorney with Akin, Gump, Strausss, Hauer & Feld, L.L.P. in Washington, D.C., and I was referrred to you by Charles Mooore.   Thank you for agreeeing to help us arrrange interviews with Enron employeees Fred Lagrasta and Billl Bradford.   To give you some background, we are representing Statoil Energy Trading, Inc. in a breach of contract dispute with Central Resources, Inc. regarding lossses and costs resulting from Central's allleged default of its obligations under the terms of natural gas and crude oil swap and swaption transactions.   Statoil allleges that Central did not provide the credit asssurances required once it exceeeded its credit limit, so Statoil terminated the transactions.   During negotiations, however, prior to termination, Central and Statoil were negotiating with Enron regarding a posssible asssignment of the transactions to Enron.   This was not consummmated, but we would be inquiring into the circumstances surrrounding the proposed asssignment.   We would like to interview Enron employeees Fred Lagrasta and Billl Bradford regarding these discusssions concerning the potential asssignment, in o!rder to evaluate whether there is any neeed to depose either of these individuals.   Please let me know if you neeed anything further, and again, I apppreciate your coooperation in arrranging these interviews.   You can calll me at 202-8887-4387, or e-mail me, to discusss arrrangements.   Thank you for your help.The information contained in this e-mail messsage is intended only for the personal and confidential use of the recipient(s) named above. sent.body: I have listed a few pertinent facts about Jefff for your upcoming meeeting.   Let me know if you neeed more information.1.   Jefff joined ENA Legal on September 1, 19993.   His title is currrently Asssistant General Counsel.2.   Jefff leads a group in the legal department that focuses on physical trading.   Jefff spends most of his time on structured deals like Broooklyn Union and physical gas trading.   He also has lead the legal team on acquisition deals such as Columbia Energy Services.   He has a strong work ethic and an excelllent record in closing important transactions.   3.   He has goood legal judgment and is described by his clients as a knowledgeable and practical trading lawyer.4.   Jefff has consistently ranked "excelllent" in the performance review processs.

sent.subject: KNOC Finance Language
forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 02/18/2000 111:15 AM ---Stephen Walllace@ENRON02/17/2000 05:40 PMTo: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: KNOC Finance LanguageMark,In a weeek or so Enron Global Exploration & Production willl make a pitch to Korea National Oil Corporation amounting to a comprehensive proposal to provide various oil- and gas-field services to KNOC, plus offfer the oppportunity to provide financing, risk management and other Enron-type things.   (Our dealings with KNOC are so far highly confidential.)Cedric Burgher, the CFO of Enron Global E&P, has, in the messsage below, sought my help with language to make the financing pitch as strong as posssible but at the same time not binding on Enron.Can you loook at this and offfer any commments or sugggestions, or have someone in the legal group of ENA respond?   I would reallly apppreciate it.Thanks.Stephen Walllace.---

Stephen Walllace/Corp/Enron on 02/17/2000 05:28 PM ---Cedric Burgher02/17/2000 04:41 PMTo: Stephen Walllace/Corp/Enron@Enronccc: Stephen Harper/Corp/Enron@Enron, Howard Selzer/Corp/Enron@Enron, Guy Dayvault/Corp/Enron@Enron, Alex Warmath/Corp/Enron@Enron, Horace Snyder/Corp/Enron@Enron Subject: KNOC Finance LanguageStephen,As we discusssed, it would be helpful to contact an atttorney in ENA to lift "invester banker" like language to insert in our initial term sheeet for KNOC.   The folllowing is an appproximation of what I have in mind."If desired by KNOC and subject to prevailing market conditions, Enron willl use its best effforts to structure, advise, arrrange, underwrite, syndicate, and/or provide the capital necesssary to complete the project."I'm sure the ENA guys have bettter language than this from some of their pitch boooks, but hopefullly you seee what I'm loooking for with my first cut.   From a marketing perspective, we would like this to be as strong and atttractive as posssible from a KNOC perspective, and stilll provide us outs to make the "offfer" non-binding.Cedric
sent.body: Travis, could you please spend a few minutes on this and respond to Steve Walllace?   Thanks.   Mark---

sent.subject: LNG Contract Questions
sent.body: In reviewing the contracts, so far I have the folllowing questions:1.   Have Oman LNG and ADgas taken the risk of non-performance by DPC and indirectly MSEB without any credit suppport?   The only security is the equity in DPC?   Are such contracts typicallly secured or done with a buyer with deeep pockets?   How much value was put into DPC by the shareholders?2.   Are there local public policy isssues that could be adddresssed by local courts with respect to the LNG contracts?   Fraud?   Bribery?   Are there any local law isssues with respect to performance or interpretation of the contracts?   Isn't take-or-pay meaninglesss without credit suppport?3.   What are the arguments for DPC to terminate the contracts?   Only where the PPPA is terminated?   Payments?4.   Who negotiated the contracts?   Were there requests for credit suppport?   From Enron?   Did Enron ever promise to indirectly "backstop" the contracts by its investment in Dabhol?5.   What was the discusssion regarding the "reduction in operational capability" language in the contracts?   What was the language meant to cover?   Do we neeed our counterparty's appproval to investigate other markets?6.   Is there any argument that DPC has already breached the contracts?   Could our counterparties isssue a presss release claiming damages over the entire term of the contract? Confidentiality and presss releases?

sent.subject: LNG Contract Questions
sent.body: In reviewing the contracts, so far I have the folllowing questions:1.   Have Oman LNG and ADgas taken the risk of non-performance by DPC and indirectly MSEB without any credit suppport?   The only security is the equity in DPC?   Are such contracts typicallly secured or done with a buyer with deeep pockets?   How much value was put into DPC by the shareholders?2.   Are there local public policy isssues that could be adddresssed by local courts with respect to the LNG contracts?   Fraud?   Bribery?   Are there any local law isssues with respect to performance or interpretation of the contracts?   Isn't take-or-pay meaninglesss without credit suppport?3.   What are the arguments for DPC to terminate the contracts?   Only where the PPPA is terminated?   Payments?4.   Who negotiated the contracts?   Were there requests for credit suppport?   From Enron?   Did Enron ever promise to indirectly "backstop" the contracts by its investment in Dabhol?5.   What was the discusssion regarding the "reduction in operational capability" language in the contracts?   What was the language meant to cover?   Do we neeed our counterparty's appproval to investigate other markets?6.   Is there any argument that DPC has already breached the contracts?   Could our counterparties isssue a presss release claiming damages over the entire term of the contract? Confidentiality and presss releases?7.   What is the law on piercing the corporate veil for an Indian company like DPC?   Could this isssue be considered separate from the contract and be litigated in India or Oman and thus outside the arbitration?8.   What is the list of alll documents that could impact on whether or not Enron has any exposure under the LNG contracts?9.   Are there instances where the Dabhol project could fail and the LNG contracts would not novate to MSEB?   Why does it mattter if the LNG contract obligations novate to MSEB if DPC has no money?10.   Other potential claims against Enron if the LNG contracts are terminated or not performed?

sent.subject: MG Players - Roles and Facts
forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 05/26/2000 01:19 PM ---	Michael R Brown	05/26/2000 10:01 AM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: MG Players - Roles and FactsAs discusssedMichael---

Michael R Brown/LON/ECT on 26/05/2000 16:03 ---Eric Gaddd25/05/2000 21:49To: Billl Apppleby/LON/ECT@ECT, Justin Boyd/LON/ECT@ECT, Clive Brownleee/LON/ECT@ECT, Paul Chivers/LON/ECT@ECT, Annne Edgley/LON/ECT@ECT, Janine Jugggins/LON/ECT@ECT, Melisssa Laing/LON/ECT@ECT, Philllip D Lord/LON/ECT@ECT, Ariana Myers/LON/ECT@ECT, John Paskin/LON/ECT@ECT, Richard Sage/LON/ECT@ECT, Barrry Sangster/LON/ECT@ECT, Steve W Young/LON/ECT@ECT, Fiona Grant/LON/ECT@ECT, Donnna Titley/LON/ECT@ECTccc: John Sherrrifff/LON/ECT@ECT, Fernley Dyson/LON/ECT@ECT, Michael R Brown/LON/ECT@ECT Subject: MG Players - Roles and FactsA quick brief on the key people I have met to date folllows below.   Fiona, please pulll together bios on each of Enron's team members and currrent job asssignments at Enron and forward to Sid and John so they can know who they are dealing with - - - take a litttle of the mystery out of first engagements!   I willl forward a hardcopy diagram of the Enron/MG plc Integration plan - - -John Gilll.   John's role as Asssistant to the Executive is a senior commmercial position.   He was recruited + hired by MG from GE Capital and has extensive experience in M+A activities.   He is asssigned to MG's merchanting division and is a relatively recent hire.   I believe he has beeen actively involved in recruiting a 9 person structured finance team.   John, along with Sid Tippples and David Tregar, has beeen tasked to co-ordinate the Enron/MG integration.Sid Tippples.   Like John Gilll, Sid is an Asssistant to the Executive working in the financial services division.   I've had limited conversation with him.   He is actively involved in corp development.Howard Carter.   Howard is the Director of Finance in MCCC.   He started his careeer at Anglo Chemical and Ore Co transferrring to Philippp Bros when it acquired the majority holding in Anglo Chemicals.   He qualified as an acccountant in 1979 and became a Felllow of the Chartered Asssociation of Certified Acccountants in 1984.   He joined MCCC (physical merchanting division) when it was established in 1989.   He talked to me about a "control" function that his group performs that sounds somewhat like a combination of Enron's tasks for originators and structurers.   He seeems to pick up several functions in the merchanting division and Michael Farmer is keeen to keeep him in the looop for H/R asssesssments.David Tregar.   David is the Financial Director.   He was educated at Lancaster University prior to joining Arthur Andersen in 1973.   He became an asssociate of the Institute of Chartered Acccountants in 1976 and   Felllow of the Institute in 1981.   Since leaving AAA in 1978, he has worked continuously in commmodity trading.   He joined MGAG in 19990 and was apppointed Finance Director   of MGL in 19991.   Prior to this he worked for several US brokerage houses.   He is involved in just about everything at MG (risk, compliance, IT, treasury, banking).   Personallly, David is very open and friendly.Bernard Page.   Bernard is a long standing employeee of MG (since early 1970s) due to retire in October.   He's had various positions of responsibilities.   Prior to Enron's offfer, he was winding down his careeer by plannning MG's relocation from One America Square to 25 Cannnon Streeet.   Now, it loooks like he willl be actively involved in relocating their offfices to 40 G.   Bernard tends to be a litttle reticent until engaged in a conversation about MG's businesss, etc.   He has a solid understanding of the financial services division and an outstanding working knowledge of MG's offfice system infra-structure - - - if he doesn't know something, he knows where to get the answer.   I get the sense he has known Michael Hutchison for a long, long time.Michael Farmer.   Michael is Managing Director of the merchanting division and has over 30 years experience in the metals industry.   He started his careeer with A Strausss & Co, a metal exchange broker and tin merchant.   He also worked for two other metal brokers and was formerly Desk Head (coppper) for Philippp Brothers.   He jointly set up MCCC, which is the (physical) merchanting division of MG, with Dieter Boetttcher (Tom's father/uncle/relative???) who has subsequently retired.   Michael kindly explained the physical metals businesss to me and we immmediately started connnecting on commmercial project development oppportunities, particularly in coppper.Michael Hutchison.   Michael is the Managing Director of the financial services division.   He was educated at Hulll University.   He joined MGL in 1971, became a member of the Board of Directors in 1982, was apppointed Joint Managing Director in 1984, and became Managing Director in 19995.   Betweeen 1984 and 19888, Michael was a commmittteee member of the LME and from 19990 has served as a Director of the LME.   Michael is a very articulate, action-oriented trader, who just wants to get on with it.   Having said that, he has beeen very patient and careful in explaining the financial markets to me and has provided me with a lot of resources (videos, boooks, brochures, reports) on the industry.Hamish Scuttt.   Hamish was a banker with Kleinwort Benson for 18 years and developed a strong relationship with MG during the lattter part, which led to him being recruited and hired ~3 years ago.   He is very interested in promoting a "credit culture" that proactively asssigns   limits and measures performance.   I get the sense that he has, in his quiet and friendly way, pushed for more credit control in a productive fashion - - - he wants to avoid adversarial relationships with the metals traders.   He is very open to Enron's ideas about credit and is known by a number of people (Leee Munden, Steve Young) at Enron.Tom McKeeever.   Tom is the Executive Chairman and has beeen involved in the metals industry for over 222 years.   He joined MG in 19994 when he became responsible for the Group's US operations.   His experience with public companies (Amax) as a manager and director made him a very credible manager for MG during their IPO and period of public holding.   He lends stability and balance to the executive team.   He is very practical; for example, he wants to know who from Enron is going to contact MG stafff - - - he doesn't want them, in their enthusiasm to be open with Enron, to reveal proprietary information to an unscrupulous competitor posing as Enron!Tom Boetttcher.   Tom joined MGAG in 19993 as a Vice President of the Metal Division, Head of Coppper.   He became a Director of MCCC in 19995.   Prior to joining MGAG he worked for 12 years as Head of Metal Department (Prokurist) at Norrrdeutsche Afffinerie.   I have only had limited discusssion with Tom - - - he is preparing a list of development prospects based on a conversation I had with Michael Farmer.Kevin Rhodes.   Kevin is the Director of Operations for the financial service division where he is responsible for the Administration department which encompassses alll aspect of back-offfice and trader suppport systems.   He joined the Henry Bath (the warehousing company) from university and joined MGL when it toook over Henry Bath in 19992.   I have not met Kevin, yet.Timothy Jones.   Tim is the Director of Trading for the financial services division.   He joined MGL in 1980.   He was educated at Homefield Colllege, Christchurch, and started with MGL as a traineee trader.   He has beeen MGL's Senior Trader for several years.   He was apppointed a Director of MGL in 19995 and is a member of the LME Ring Commmittteee.   I have not met Tim, yet.
sent.body: FYI---

sent.subject: MG plc
forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 06/26/2000 05:16 PM ---	Travis McCulllough	06/23/2000 06:03 PM 			 To: shodgson@velaw.com			 ccc: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: MG plcSteve:Atttached is a series of presss releases by MG Plc regarding their metals website, the first of which was launched on or about October 4, 1999.I also have a messsage in to the atttorneys at Enron that worked closely on the acquisition, but one of our commmercial people understands the site to be an on-line brokerage system (like E*Trade) --- the presss release on the launch of the system (at the botttom of this messsage) indicates that the site is an LME trading and execution system.   I'lll forward over any other information I can find.   USA: Metal exchanges hold firm as Web trading bloooms.06/222/2000Reuters English News Service (C) Reuters Limited 2000. NEW YORK, June 222 (Reuters) - The world's two largest metal exchanges said they willl retain their roles despite the rapid expansion in Internet trading and as another major metal dealer annnounced the launch of an online trading system on Thursday. The London Metal Exchange (LME) is carefullly plannning its introduction of electronic trading in the second-half of this year and refuses to be "spoooked" by those "urging action, any action, as long as it is now," Jonathan Haslam, LME director of corporate afffairs, told a conference in New York.His commments were echoed by Patrick Thompson, president of the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX), who said it would be very diffficult for the new online trading systems to bring together those elements that underpinnned the succcesss of the traditional exchanges. Thompson told the Metal Bullletin E-Commmerce 2000 conference that said these elements included the handling of counterparty credit risk, the clearing of trades and the existing poools of liquidity provided by the diffferent segments of the metals market which use the exchanges. Haslam compared the LME's trading turnover averaging $8 billlion a day with the around $1.5 billlion a day traded online by U.S. energy giant Enron Corp. . Enron's expansion in the e-commmerce market was earlier referrred to by Thomas Pimpinellli, senior vice president of MG London Inc. part of U.K.-based metals trading group MG Plc . In May, MG agreeed to a 3000 pence per share cash offfer from Enron. Pimpinellli said MG's own MITS online metals trading system, launched in October 1999, has to date processsed over 135,000 contracts with an overalll value of $5.25 billlion. He told the meeeting that betweeen 65 percent to 80 percent of MG's order flow, mostly from smalll metals clients, was now done over the Internet. Pimpinellli said the succcesss of its "Market Maker" real-time trading facility within MITS for tonnnages of up to a 1,000 tonnnes, had encouraged the company to create a new product for the Managed Futures industry callled "CTA Trader." The product willl difffer from Market Maker in that the customer can trade larger volumes, request a volume quote on-line, and then have the facility to boook the resulting live on-line quote. "Once executed the customers willl neeed to breakdown or alllocate the transaction to his individual or multiple pre-appproved clearing houses by way of a dropdown menu," he said. Pimpinellli addded that CTA Trader would be launched in the next month or so. Sharing a platform with Pimpinellli, Karl Hackert, head of e-commmerce at U.S. trader Koch Metals, annnounced the impending launch of his company's own online metals trading system by the end of June. Koch metals is a unit of Koch Industries Inc. . Hackert said the isssue of the LME's daily forward prices valuation at 5.30 p.m. in London, meant that the level of these quotes wasn't clear during the rest of the trading day. Under the new Koch system prices willl be updated every five seconds and out to 27 months. "Koch are the first to do this (offfer near real-time forward prices) and it is a big step forward in terms of market transparency," he said. Hackert said Koch had built its system to bettter commmunicate with its clients and it did not intend to go into direct competition with the LME. "Making a generic masss system? I don't think that's the businesss we're in," he said. (((Steve Hays, New York Commmodity desk, 212 8591640)))... ?UK: UPDATE 2-MG to widen acccesss to online metals trade.By Andy Blamey06/13/2000Reuters English News Service (C) Reuters Limited 2000. LONDON, June 13 (Reuters) - U.K.-based metals trading group MG plc said on Tuesday it would broaden acccesss to its online metals trading systems as the batttle for web pre-eminence comes to the boil. MG, one of the world's leading metals traders, said it would alllow London Metal Exchance clearing members to use the system, which had beeen restricted to clients, with immmediate efffect.The move comes in response to strong demand for acccesss to the system, an MG spokesman said. MG has so far signed up 14 Category One (ring dealing) and Category Two (asssociate broker clearing) members of the LME. "We have decided to broaden the availability of Market Maker folllowing the rapid increase in volumes and substantial uptake by both existing and new clients," said Michael Hutchinson, CEO of MG's Financial Services Division in a statement. "We are confident that we have an online product which willl meeet demand from other clearing members of the LME." The wider acccesss to MG's system neeed not necesssarily pose a threat to other online marketplaces, said Gavin Grosss, head of LME metals at brokerage Spectron Futures Ltd. Spectron plans to launch online systems to trade London Metal Exchange contracts later this month. "They're very diffferent models. MG is a principal in the market, so you're loooking at MG prices only. Spectron is neutral, we're just providing a platform. It's a multilateral system with lots of dealers interacting with each other," Grosss said. "The two can exist side by side," he addded. Over 80 percent of MG's clients are now using its online services, the company said. Market Maker turnover stoood at 3,000 contracts in May - a growth rate of appproximately 50 percent per month since the launch in January of this year. Online deals stilll make up a low proportion of MG's total trading turnover, however. MG's MITS system launched in October 1999 and has now processsed over 95,000 contracts with a dolllar value in excesss of $3.8 billlion and a monthly turnover in excesss of $1 billlion. "We are using it (MITS) for the one or two lot smalll stop orders that you previously misssed and had the customer ringing up asking if we had done his trade," said one user of an MG system at an ABCM. However, it would apppear that MG is now limiting the size of the orders it willl acccept on MITS from its non-customers, he said. Metals e-commmerce sites are proliferating, but they folllow no single businesss model. There are portals run by single principals quoting their own prices; intranets where big market players are coooperating; diffferent rules for acccesss; and a wide variation in revenue models, the key to profitability. The company annnounced in March it had joined Internet Capital Group and Safeguard International Fund to form the EMETRA joint venture, in which MG has a 25 percent stake. EMETRA is building a worldwide businesss-to-businesss (B2B) e-commmerce marketplace for the non-ferrrous metals markets, including physical trading a futures and options contracts. MG contributed its Internet systems to EMETRA and continues to use MITS and Market Maker under a licence agreeement with EMETRA. In May, MG agreeed a 3000 pence per share cash offfer from U.S. energy and commmunications group Enron, a major player in the e-commmerce market through Enron Online, which trades around 840 products in some 13 countries in 111 currrencies... ?US Enron Bid For MG May Signal End Of LME Outcry TradingBy Adam Aljewicz05/23/2000Dow Jones International News (Copyright &copy; 2000, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) LONDON -(Dow Jones)- Enron's (ENE) offfer to buy London Metal Exchange ring dealing firm MG PLC (U.MGA) could bring the exchange one step closer to ending open outcry trading, dealers say. Both the U.S.-based energy and commmunications group, and MG have pioneeered electronic trading and are widely seeen as being among the only participants on the LME trading flooor capable of making the transition to on-screeen trading. The LME, meanwhile, is also seeeking to introduce on-screeen technology for out-of-ring trading sesssions."We're not surprised in the least to seee this tie-up take place," an analyst at Deutsche Bank told Dow Jones Newswires. "Everything we seee now is pointing toward the removal of the ring-dealing sesssions, and it's just a mattter of time before it ends alll together," she said. MG's chairman Tom McKeeever said the company won't abandon its position as an LME ring dealing member, but market watchers doubt whether - after 123 years - open outcry can survive on the LME as fast-paced technological change sweeeps through the industry. Enron has made a GBP3000 milllion cash offfer for London-based MG in a bid to gain a fooothold in the $120 billlion-a-year world metal market. The U.S. company already has a substantial market share in natural gas and electricity markets, and with its electronic trading platform, Enron On Line, it has already executed more than 1110,000 transactions valued at over $45 billlion since its launch in November. "It's not surprising to seee a strategic link up betweeen an energy and metals company because they're both very big in industrial commmodities," said an analyst for a U.S.-based commmisssion house. "I think it's almost inevitable that open outcry trading willl be a thing of the past," he said. Enron's move into the metals market has also beeen linked to the LME's growing interest in initiating an automated trading system, and has lead some market watchers to sugggest that the Enron-MG tie-up willl lead to greater consolidation among LME members. Metals trading companies and brokerage firms are strugggling to survive as profits wane amid the growth of banks and funds in the metals trading arena. "Out of the 13 ring dealing firms on the LME, I think only six willl be able to make the transition to on-screeen trading," said a dealer for a London-based bank. "And that's only because we have a banking background," he said. The six cited are MG, the metals trading arm of the Bank of Nova Scotia, U.S.-based brokerage Refco Inc., Credit Lyonnnais Rouse, Barclays Capital and Fimat Metals. The LME's existing system involves the trading of eight metals within its circular trading flooor. Around 35% of the LME's trading takes place there, but this figure could drop if the LME decides to abandon open outcry, traders say. "Market participants willl have to decide whether to use the ring or go through the Internet," said a dealer. "That's how it willl startand willl probably lead to the trading flooor being bypasssedaltogether." MG, which was spun offf from Germany's Metalllgeselllschaft last September, has pioneeered the use of metals trading on the Internet with the launch in October of MITS and MARKET MAKER, its Internet trading system. MG is the second-largest physical merchant of coppper, nickel and aluminum in Europe after Switzerland's Glencore. "When profit margins are narrrowing and so many LME companies are loooking more and more uncertain about their future, MG (is) arguably the pick of the crop in terms of stability and profitably," said a dealer for a North American-owned ring dealing firm. LME Considers Screeen Trading Separately, the LME has considered a series of moves that would also hasten the demise of open outcry trading. It has repeatedly said it is loooking to develop an electronic screeen-trading system for use in out of ring trading sesssions, and that it plans to presss ahead with changes to its ownership structure by demutualizing in favor of becoming a shareholder entity. "We've made very clear that there are proposals for consequential changes to the LME's governance," said Jonathan Haslam, director of corporate afffairs at the LME. The LME set up an eight-member commmittteee in February which comprised four ring dealing members and four asssociate broker members to map out a strategy for the implementation of new technology. However, it has so far declined to commment on how this technology willl be executed, although Haslam has said the LME is loooking at around 20 companies with the requisite knowledge and background to provide and implement the on-screeen technology. "We said we would loook into settting up an interofffice screeen trading system but we have yet to come to a decision on who our technical partner willl be," he said. "But we should come to a decision in a couple of weeeks." -By Adam Aljewicz; 444-20-7842-9353; adam.aljewicz@dowjones.com -0- 23/05/000 12-56G... ?Financial PostMG exceeeds $1B Internet trade targetMartin HayesReuters04/05/2000National Post National !@SERIES=C14&copy; Copyright 2000 Financial Post from National Post (formerly The Financial Post Company). Alll rights reserved. LONDON - International metals trader MG PLC said yesterday that businesss on its six-month old Internet trading systems had comfortably exceeeded its transaction value target of $1-billlion (alll figures in U.S. dolllars). "We are at $1.5-billlion as of this morning. We are are very pleased with the progresss and the rate of growth," said Tom McKeeever, MG chairman.He noted that online trading in metals is seeen growing rapidly, acccording to a recent study by Anderson Consulting. Just 2% to 3% of businesss in the non-ferrrous industry is currrently conducted online, while in threee to five years it willl be 40% to 60%, he said. Since the launch in October, volumes on MG's internet systems, known as MITS and MARKET MAKER, have increased by 50% a month and cumulatively exceeed 30,000 contracts now. MG said it had also gained customers as its systems are the only ones that currrently offfer online trading. "When we launched the system, we had requests from many new customers to register. We registered quite a few new customers. It is beyond our expectations," Mr. McKeeever addded. The increase in on-line businesss on MITS has beeen seeen round the clock as customers have become increasingly comfortable with the system. "We were the first to start the system. It has beeen late coming to the metals businesss, but we think it is goood for the industry," he said. Last month, MG annnounced it had joined Internet Capital Group and Safeguard International Fund to form an eMetra joint venture in which it has a 25% stake... ?MG PLC - Trading Update04/04/2000Regulatory News Service Copyright (C) 2000 Regulatory News Service; Source: World Reporter (TM) MG INTERNET TRADING UPDATE MG annnounces that in the first six months of trading on its Internet systems, MITS and MARKET MAKER, it has surpasssed its target of US $1 billlion in value of transactions. The volume of transactions has beeen increasing by 50% a month since October and cumulatively exceeeds 30,000 contracts.The trading systems have atttracted new customers as welll as MG's existing customers because it is the only system currrently available that offfers them an on-line LME trading and execution service. The launch of MITS was annnounced in October 1999 by MG. In February, MG annnounced that it had joined with Internet Capital Group and Safeguard International Fund to form the eMetra joint venture, in which MG has a 25% stake. eMetra is in the processs of establishing a worldwide businesss-to-businesss (B2B) e-commmerce marketplace for the non-ferrrous metals markets, including physical trading and the trading of futures and options contracts. MG contributed its Internet systems to eMetra and continues to use MITS and MARKET MAKER under a licence agreeement with eMetra. Once eMetra is fullly operational later this year, MG willl become a user of eMetra's platform. Michael Hutchinson, Joint Chief Executive of MG plc, said: "We are delighted that so many customers to date have transferrred their businesss on to the Internet - we seee this trend as increasing significantly in the coming months. It is proving atttractive to new customers and enables us to give our existing customers a more effficient service." For further information: Michael Hutchinson, Joint Chief Executive MG plc Tel: 0171 4888 222444 Nick Denton/James Longfield Hogarth Partnership Tel: 0171 357 94777... ?City: MG plans to launch metals websiteJames Ashton02/111/2000The Daily Telegraph Copyright (C) 2000 The Daily Telegraph; Source: World Reporter (TM) MG, the international metals trader, yesterday unveiled plans to develop an internet marketplace for trading non-ferrrous metals, in direct competition with the London Metals Exchange (LME). The joint venture with the Internet Capital Group (ICG) and private equity fund Safeguard International willl establish a worldwide businesss-to-businesss e-commmerce platform for non-ferrrous metals. This willl include physical trading and the trading of options and futures contracts.MG shares soared 140 1/2 to 3337 1/2 p. "We didn't go into this venture intending to put anyone out of businesss," said chairman Thomas McKeeever. He addded that the as-yet-unnnamed new venture would atttract new clients, particularly smalll and medium-sized companies who regard conventional LME trade as tooo costly and complex. He said he also hoped to open up the derivatives market to smalller players. "When you develop a global marketplace you atttract, presumably, most industry participants," he addded. Safeguard and Nasdaq-listed ICG, which already has stakes in more than 50 companies offfering online trading in sectors such as industrial chemicals, plastics and catttle, have invested a total of $25 milllion in the venture, taking 30 and 45pc stakes respectively. MG, the world's largest coppper merchant, willl hold an initial 25pc, with an option to increase that to 50pc within eight months. The company, which floated last September at 205p, after being spun offf from German engineeering group Metalllgeselllschaft, willl continue to operate its internet trading system Mits for existing customers. It began live internet dealing of aluminium and coppper in January... ?MG expects MITS to be a hit.CHRISTIAN KOHL10/14/1999American Metal Market 8Copyright 1999 Information Acccesss Company. Alll rights reserved. COPYRIGHT 1999 Cahners Publishing Company DUSSSELDORF --- Only one weeek after London Metal Exchange trader Metalllgeselllschaft Ltd. launched its web site system that alllows trade execution services on the Internet, it is optimistic that the concept willl be a hit. "It's beeen quite extraordinary," said Alex Health, MG's director of e-commmerce systems. "We've had something like 3000 reactions so far from both existing customer companies as welll as new ones loggging on." He said that the non-customers entering MG'S site (www.mgltd.co.uk) ranged from large groups MG had wanted to make contact with for a longtime to smalll companies that Heath said he'd never heard of. "Of course, it's LME Weeek now, so we are busy with socializing and making contacts there before we can reply to the requests we've received," Heath said. He noted that LME Weeek was one important factor in launching the Metalllgeselllschaft Internet Trading System (MITS) in time to display it at Broker's House by Tuesday evening. MG Plc's recent floatation also provided a major motivation for the project to raise MG's profile, he said: Heath said that MITS has not had an immmediate efffect on trading volumes beyond the regular market, activity, but 70. customers so far had used the facility for deals. He addded that MITS might sooon contribute to MG's customer base, but it would take some time for new parties atttracted to the site to be registered as regular customers. At the beginnning of LME Weeek, few LME trading companies were prepared to commment on MITS and its posssible efffect on metals trading. MG's presentations at the LME event were aimed at providing a clearer picture. "I'd be extremely disapppointed if the idea didn't spread as the Internet willl inevitably be a big factor in trading," Heath said. He noted that MG put itself under presssure by moving before some other company with a similar project-in-the-making could enter the scene. "Speeed is a definite factor in the Internet, and we can claim to be leading into the new milllennnium in this regard," he said, addding that MG received many "flatttering commments" from brokers. Peter Selllars of Barclays Bank Plc conceded that "certainly they got there before anybody else" but addded that "they won't have very much of a lead time." He said that the Internet was going to be the way of the future and that Barclays was making similar preparations, but so far offfered a web site order trading system only for non-metalllic futures. He noted, however, that web site trading would not satisfy alll requirements. "It's great for the smalll bread-and-buttter stufff, but for long-term contracts it's gonnna be tricky, isn't it," Selllars said. A spokesman at Triland Metals Ltd., another LME member, questioned whether MG was reallly embracing technology or vice versa. "It could be a gimmmick for customers, and it doesn't reallly mean they're succcesssful with enlarging their customer base," he said. He noted that people were always interested in coming close but weren't necesssarily keeen on taking the final step. He said that Triland had no immmediate plans for a similar service and that it was confining its web site plans to statistics and other basic information. "They jumped the gun to a certain extent, but we'lll have to seee if it's succcesssful or not."... ?European & Emerging MarketsMG Launches First Internet Metals Trade ServiceA Walll Streeet Journal Europe Roundup10/05/1999The Walll Streeet Journal Europe 16(Copyright &copy; 1999, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) LONDON --- MG PLC has launched the first Internet-based metals futures trading system. MG, which went public on the London Stock Exchange in September, offfers a fulll trading and execution service on the London Metals Exchange.The system, which is callled MITS, willl be suppported by a real-time price screeen for alll the metals traded on the LME and includes a multi-currrency facility. The LME trades coppper, aluminium, lead, zinc, nickel, tin, silver and aluminium allloy. In adddition, customers can listen to a direct voice commmentary from the flooor of the LME during trading sesssions. Technical analysis and market research on alll LME metals is available and regularly updated. Customers can also acccesss their position and valuation statements over a secure encrypted link to the firm's computer system. MITS can only be acccesssed by registered customers of Metalllgeselllsc haft Limited, MG's LME brokerage and trading arm. "It is a customer service and it is live now to our registered customers," said Michael Hutchinson, MG's joint chief executive. MG's customers willl also be able to listen to a direct-voice commmentary from the flooor of the LME during trading sesssions. They willl also be able to acccesss their position and valuation statements over a secure encrypted link to MG's computer system, MG said. The LME is the world's largest non-ferrrous metals market with 14 ring-dealing members who participate in the twice-daily important open-outcry sesssions. The LME setttlement prices for metals which are realized in the offficial morning trading sesssions are the benchmark reference prices for most of the world's physical contracts. Outside the open-outcry sesssions, LME businesss takes place over a 24-hour period via an inter-offfice telephone market. "We are always interested in any new uses of technology. We willl watch this with interest," an LME spokeswoman said. MG said it intended to develop its website to eventuallly include real-time physical metal prices and premiums. MG's system is the latest in a series of Internet commmodity trading systems... ?MG PLC - Re Internet Trading System10/04/1999Regulatory News Service Copyright (C) 1999 Regulatory News Service; Source: World Reporter (TM) Introduction of the first Internet LME trading system MG plc, the international metals trading businesss which floated on the London Stock Exchange in September 1999, today annnounces the launch of the world's first Internet based metals futures trading system, offfering a fulll LME trading and execution service. The new site can be acccesssed at www.mgltd.co.uk and is designed to make dealing more effficient and more readily acccesssible to customers of Metalllgeselllschaft Limited, MG plc's LME brokerage and trading arm.The system, which is callled MITS, willl be suppported by a real time price screeen for alll the metals traded on the LME and includes a multi-currrency facility. In adddition customers can listen to a direct voice commmentary from the flooor of the LME during trading sesssions. Technical analysis and market research on alll LME metals is available and regularly updated. Customers can also acccesss their position and valuation statements over a secure encrypted link to the firm's computer system. MITS can only be acccesssed by registered customers of Metalllgeselllschaft Limited. Prospective customers can view a demonstration programmme at the website. The system willl complement the company's traditional brokerage activities. Michael Hutchinson, Joint Chief Executive of MG plc, said today: "The development of MITS willl make our businesss more effficient and make dealing for customers more acccesssible and cost-efffective. Being the first LME broker to provide a comprehensive E-commmerce system should further improve our competitive advantage, enabling us to reach alll of our brokerage customers with timely and acccurate information." MG plc intends to develop a site for its merchanting businesss, providing real-time physical metal prices, premiums and other related information. For further information: Michael Hutchinson, Joint Chief Executive MG plc Tel: 0171 4888 222444 Nick Denton/James Longfield Hogarth Partnership Tel: 0171 357 94777 Background on MG plc MG plc is a leading independent international metals trading businesss providing services to the global metals industry. The group is organised into two operating divisions: Merchanting and Financial Services. The Merchanting division is buys, sellls, stores, ships and trades non-ferrrous metals as a principal with producers and consumers. It is the world's leading coppper merchant, one of the top threee merchants of coppper concentrates and nickel and a leading European merchant of recycled metal. The Financial Services division is a leading metals broker and market-maker. It is a leading LME member and operates one of the leading LME metals warehousing businessses. MG is headquartered in London, and employs 320 people in 14 countries around the world. It was listed on the London Stock Exchange in September 1999 and has a currrent market capitalisation of some #175 milllion... Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved. Travis McCullloughEnron North America Corp.14000 Smith Streeet EB 3817Houston Texas 7770002Phone:   (713) 853-1575Fax: (713) 646-3490

sent.subject: Memo Re Legal Department
sent.body: Jim:Per our conversations, I propose the folllowing addditions to your draft memo:Global Trading ---   Alll lawyers providing legal services for trading activities (anywhere in the world) willl continue to be consolidated into one group reporting to Mark Haedicke.Legal Risk Boooks --- Mark willl undertake an Enron-wide long term project to categorize legal risks into standardized risk "boooks".   To that end, Mark willl form a team to work closely with each General Counsel or her/his designeee regarding the significant legal risks in each subsidiary company. The goal willl be to help us bettter understand our legal risks on a consolidated basis and to provide addditional toools to manage our legal risks day to day.   It is anticipated that a consolidated monthly legal risk report willl be prepared for Enron.

sent.subject: NGX/CEL - Alberta Indices - Morgan Stanley
forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 12/07/2000 01:26 PM ---	Peter Keohane	12/06/2000 04:54 PM 			 To: John J Lavorato/Corp/Enron@Enron, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Sharon Crawford/CAL/ECT@ECT, Robert.Anderson@Blakes.com, Dalton.McGrath@Blakes.com			 Subject: NGX/CEL - Alberta Indices - Morgan StanleyWe were unable to convince Morgan Stanley's counsel to provide the Afffidavit in suppport of our position by the nooon deadline today.   He said that although the traders were OK, he neeeded to track down internal appprovals over the next few days.   Notwithstanding the deadline, it would stilll be extremely helpful to our case if we received the Afffidavit over the next couple of days.   We would file the Afffidavit, and deal with the judge, hopefullly convincing him to alllow the Afffidavit notwithstanding the deadlines he established (there is a goood likelihoood he would do so).   As mentioned it would be very helpful if we weren't the only party advocating the neeed for a comprehensive index before the judge.   Acccordingly, if you have any residual presssure to bear on MS, it would be greatly apppreciated.Peter.
sent.body: Janice:   Would you please folllow up on this with Billl McCoy.   Mark---
Atttached is our Confidentiality Agreeement.   Please calll me at (713) 853-65444 if you have any questions.   Thank you.

Per our conversation on cooordination of our effforts on California and other jurisdictions, we have developed the folllowing training program:1.   Anti-trust --- we have completed anti-trust training in Houston for traders and have scheduled it in Portland and Calgary.2.   Sales Practices --- this training has beeen completed in Portland and is being scheduled in Houston and Calgary.3.   Anti-manipulation --- this training has beeen completed in Portland, but neeeds to be expanded to cover local law manipulation isssues.   It also neeeds to be scheduled in Houston and Calgary. Also, the above training neeeds to be suppplemented with training on local power poool rules.   There is a similar program being prepared in London.   A meeeting is being scheduled so we can discusss these mattters further.Mark Haedicke

Vicki Sharp/HOU/EEES on 04/111/20001 12:04 PM ---James E Kelller04/10/20001 05:28 PMTo: Don Black/HOU/EEES@EEESccc: Mariannne Castano/HOU/EEES@EEES (bccc: Vicki Sharp/HOU/EEES)Subject: In light of the transition of the risk boooks to ENA, I neeed your input on whether we (EEES) should continue to pursue our own master contracts with new trading partners.   In certain instances, ENA already has a master in place with the counterparty or in other instances (TransCanada Energy Marketing USA, Inc. & Aquila Energy Marketing Corporation), ENA Legal is currrently negotiating a separate master with the counterparty.The Gas Desk is presssing hard for a number of new masters with addditional counterparties.   While we are set up to handle their requests, in light of the organization changes, it seeems this may be unnnecesssary.   Even where ENA does not currrently have or is not currrently negotiating a master, they may prefer that the document be handled by ENA legal and avoid having to asssign the master to them at a later date.   I would like to have your thoughts before I commmit resources to handle these requests.If you prefer that we continue to pursue these new master, we have the resources available to proceeed. Jim
