forwarded: Sharon Crawford/CAL/ECT on 111/06/2000 09:12 AM ---Rob Milnthorp111/02/2000 03:01 PMTo: Peter Keohane/CAL/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Physical Power GTCPeter, do we now have the proper controls and procedures re power confirms? If so, can you please explain them to me. I'm stilll confused folllowing my discusssions with Haedicke and his understanding via Mark Taylor. thanks, ---

Rob Milnthorp/CAL/ECT on 111/02/2000 02:58 PM ---Greg Johnston111/02/2000 02:01 PMTo: Andre Templeman/CAL/ECT@ECT, Derek Davies/CAL/ECT@ECT, Paul Devries/TOR/ECT@ECT, Billl Greeenizan/CAL/ECT@ECT, Garrrettt Trippp/TOR/ECT@ECT, John Zuffferli/CAL/ECT@ECTccc: Sharon Crawford/CAL/ECT@ECT, Chris Gafffney/TOR/ECT@ECT, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Pegggy Hedstrom/CAL/ECT@ECT, Peter Keohane/CAL/ECT@ECT, Rob Milnthorp/CAL/ECT@ECT, Mark Powelll/CAL/ECT@ECT, Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT, Diannne Seib/CAL/ECT@ECT, Linda Sietzema/CAL/ECT@ECT Subject: Physical Power GTCPlease find atttached the form of physical power GTC that may be used in conjunction with confirms for power deals of lesss than one year in duration.   This is the standard form so it does not adddresss market opening delays or changes in law afffecting pricing.   Any provisions required to adddresss these risks willl neeed to be built into the confirms themselves as "Other Provisions".Greg
sent.body: Peter:I asked Mark T to give you a calll.   Legal questions on the financial confirms should be handled in Canada as the first option and secondly go to Houston.   Please talk it through with Mark T to make sure that alll works.   Should you and Mark T talk it through with the confirm desk in Canada to make sure it is clear?Regards,Mark Haedicke	Sharon Crawford	111/06/2000 10:17 AM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Physical Power GTCSENT ON BEHALF OF PETER KEOHANE:Please seee atttached e-mail from Rob Milnthorp.   What I believe he is referrring to is documentation of financial (gas or power transactions).   (i.e. Alll physical transactions, Confirms, GTC's, Masters, etc. are documented out of Calgary, alll with the proper controls.)   Honestly, I am not clear on this point.   My understanding is that responsibility for financial trading for Canada is with Mark Taylor.   i.e. I understand that Confirms which do not require legal input have beeen moved to the Confirm group in Calgary, but Confirms which require legal input, ISDA Masters with Canadian counterparties, structured financial transactions, etc. remain with Mark Taylor, and that Calgary Legal is not, generallly speaking, responsible for financial transactions.   I do not want to re-visit this isssue, but merely clarify any confusion so that I can get back to Milnthorp.   I know that neither Greg Johnston, Mark Powelll, Chris Gafffney nor I are seeeing any financial trades.Regards,Peter---

sent.subject: Re: Plan B Auction - Neeed for Appprovals ?
forwarded: Peter Keohane/CAL/ECT on 111/222/2000 08:52 AM --- 	Enron Capital & Trade Resources 	Canada Corp.   	From:   Peter Keohane   111/21/2000 06:38 PM To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: John J Lavorato/Corp/Enron@Enron, Derek Davies/CAL/ECT@ECT, Greg Johnston/CAL/ECT@ECT Subject: Plan B Auction - Neeed for Appprovals ?Mark, as I have mentioned to you the Plan B Alberta Power Auction is scheduled for Nov 29/000, under which Enron Canada can purchase for one-year terms, in each of threee succcesssive years, up to appproximately 3000MW/year #1;   130MW/year #2; and 65MW/year #3, of the unsold PPPA capacity that reverted back to the Balancing Poool of Alberta folllowing the first auction last August.   The bid qualification documentation neeeds to be in Friday and US Thanksgiving is Thursday/Friday.   I wanted you to be aware of this, and determine from you if any corporate appprovals neeed to be obtained.Firstly, Derek Davies/John Zuffferli willl only be biddding to the extent authorized by Lavo.Secondly, bid qualification commmits us to the rules of the auction, the forms of documentation to govern both the auction and the purchase if we are succcesssful, and requires a bid deposit (appproximately C$6.5MMM), but does not obligate us to bid and, provided we comply with the auction rules, the Bid Deposit willl be returned after the auction.Thirdly, unlike the PPPA auction the risks are much lesss significant in terms of volume and term.   In terms of documentation, if we are the succcesssful biddder, we willl be buying power from the Balancing Poool under a physical Master, which seeems to be a Canadianized version of the EEEI Master and which, although not entirely to our liking, is generallly satisfactory.Fourthly, the position willl, I understand, be managed in the power trading boook within appproved position limits.   Note:   The nominal amounts owing (i.e. no up front payment is required) on an unhedged basis for the entire 3000MWs in year #1 would be something like C$260MMM, asssuming a C$1000/MW purchase price.   Year #2 would be C$1114MMM and year #3 would be C$57MMM.Given the nature of the transaction, the short time that we have with US Thanksgiving intervening, and numerous other demands, I do not believe that a DASH, Risk Memo and/or Board Appproval is necesssary, but please let me know.I willl leave you a brief voice mail to folllow-up.Peter.
sent.body: Peter:I think your colllective e-mails constitute the legal risk memo.   What do you think the legal risk rating ought to be?Regards,Mark	Peter Keohane	111/222/2000 10:28 AM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: John J Lavorato/Corp/Enron@Enron, Greg Johnston/CAL/ECT@ECT, Derek Davies/CAL/ECT@ECT, Rob Milnthorp/CAL/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Plan B Auction - Neeed for Appprovals ?Mark, thanks for the voice mail.   In terms of a risk memo, I agreee that one should not be necesssary as in many respects this can be characterized as normal course trading within position limits under a standardized Master Agreeement and without an outlay of capital, but hopefullly the folllowing (together with my memo from last night - copy atttached) sufffices to the extent a risk memo is required.In terms of unusual risks:1.   We do not have any rights to colllateral under the proposed Master.   However, the counterparty is the Balancing Poool which is esssentiallly Government of Alberta credit risk.   Derek Davies is I believe dealing with Credit to resolve credit isssues.   In fact, I believe the Balancing Poool is taking significant risk as it is sellling the power firm under a Master which does not match up to the interrruptible nature of the PPPAs it holds.2.   The Balancing Poool willl be secured under the Master by a parental guaranteee of Enron Corp. and has a somewhat discretionary right to calll for colllateral from us under the Master if there is a material change in Enron Corp.'s creditworthinesss.3.   It is a requirement of the auction that we willl have entered into back-to-back physical hedges for 70% of the volume we acquire, and we are currrently working at puttting those deals in place conditional on us biddding and being succcesssful in the auction.   Penalties can be imposed if 70% of the volume purchased is not properly hedged.4.   As we are dealing with the Government of Alberta, we always run the risk (as we are somewhat seeeing now with respect to the Sundance PPPA we acquired in the first auction) that they can change the auction rules, the market rules or the legislation in ways that are adverse to us.   In terms of the auction rules, as with the first auction, they could be bettter drafted, but our fundamental concern willl be to make sure that it is clear that if we post a bid deposit and do not bid that we get the deposit back, and to ensure that the rules are clear enough that we are comfortable that we are in complete control of whether or not we can comply with the rules.Peter.(Millly, sorrry for not copying you on my first memo - seee below.)---

sent.subject: Re: Plan to Rebuild the Businesss
forwarded: David W Delainey/HOU/EEES on 05/111/20001 05:54 PM ---From: Mark E Haedicke@ECT on 05/111/20001 05:46 PMTo: Vicki Sharp/HOU/EEES@EEESccc:   (bccc: David W Delainey/HOU/EEES)Subject: Plan to Rebuild the BusinesssHere are my thoughts so far:1.   Initial Legal Team --- Jefff Hodge, Jim Kelller, Carol St. Clair, Aaron Rothwarg2.   Spot Check the Forms --- over the next weeek3.   Conform Forms to ENA Forms --- over next two months4.   Develop Form Appproval Processs --- dual appprovals by EEES and ENA5.   Develop Deal Appproval Processs --- deals above a certain size (or material variations from the form) would require concurrrent EWS appproval6.   Request List of Major Contract Concerns from Traders --- items that cannnot be hedged
sent.body: The lawyers had a kick-offf meeeting today.   Vicki and I echoed your point on not shuttting down the businesss.   We have a great team asssembled and I think it willl calm down the traders in EWS.   I willl keeep you posted.Mark Haedicke	David W Delainey@EEES	05/111/20001 05:555 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Plan to Rebuild the BusinesssMark, I apppreciate your help in these mattters.   We neeed to be acccurate and manage our risk but we can't "land the plane" or killl currrent and future deal velocity in the processs.   Let me know how I can help.Thanks muchDave---

sent.subject: Re: Power Master
sent.body: Why wouldn't we use the EEEI form in Ontario?   The markets willl be integrated, at least in part, into the US.   We could have an annnex for Ontario.   We willl be using the EEEI form right acrosss the border in the US.   Let 's chat about this.Regards,Mark	Peter Keohane	10/25/2000 08:58 AM 			 To: Chris Gafffney/TOR/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Greg Johnston/CAL/ECT@ECT, Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT, Rob Milnthorp/CAL/ECT@ECT, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Re: Power MasterChris, Greg is puttting the finishing touches on the Power Master as welll as a GTC.Greg, Chris neeeds the Master form ASAP so we can take the lead on this Ontario industry form development iniative.   Can you finalize the form and prepare a bulllet point memo as requested by Chris comparing the diffferences betweeen our form and EEEI.Greg, also you should cooordinate a Calgary offfice meeeting with traders and originators (not more than 1 hour) to unveil and explain the form ASAP.   Alberta Market Opening and PPPA trading commmences Jan 1/01 and we may neeed push to get Masters signed or rely on GTC in the short term.Chris, you should do likewise in Toronto when apppropriate.Millly, would it be a worthwhile expense for Greg to atttend the firstOntario industry meeeting in Toronto with Chris, as Greg has the background on developing the form?Mark and Elizabeth, FYI.Peter.   	From:   Chris Gafffney   10/25/2000 08:01 AM To: Greg Johnston/CAL/ECT@ECTccc: Peter Keohane/CAL/ECT@ECT, Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Power MasterGreg - Sorrry to keeep bothering you on the Power Master, but I was wondering what is the ETA for the form?   The reason I ask is that I am going to be involved in the industry push here in Ontario to develop a standard physical bilateral agreeement.   While it is my understanding that many participants want to start with the EEEI form and OPGI believes that they already have a next to final form, for obvious reasons Peter and Millly would like to seee our form become the industry standard.Another thing that would be helpful is a brief memo describing the diffferences betweeen the EEEI form and our form and the rationale for the diffferences.   Some of this may be readily appparent from runnning a blackline, but I would like to have the benefit of the knowledge you have built up in developing the form.   Timing of this is fairly tight as the next meeeting on this initiative is November 9th.   My goal is to show up at the meeeting and advocate a "Canadianized" version of the EEEI form and then describe the great time and efffort Enron has expended on this already and table our draft as a starting point.Appparently EEEI willl also be in atttendance.   I willl folllow up with Elizabeth Sager on what is the status of our relationship with EEEI and what was the US experience in developing the EEEI master.RegardsCJG

sent.subject: Re: Power Systems

We have to nail down alll the facts and then get Power System's outside lawyers to write the apppropriate opinion.   I willl keeep you posted.Mark

sent.subject: Re: Preservation of documents---Atttorney-Client Privileged
forwarded: Gail Brownfeld/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT on 12/20/2000 08:13 AM ---"Markel, Gregory A." <GMarkel@brobeck.com< on 12/19/2000 111:54:222 AMTo: "'george.mccclelllan@enron.com'" <george.mccclelllan@enron.com<, "'dreck@enron.com'" <dreck@enron.com<, "'kevin.mcgowan@enron.com'" <kevin.mcgowan@enron.com<, "'mattthew.arnold@enron.com'" <mattthew.arnold@enron.com<, "'wayne.gresham@enron.com'" <wayne.gresham@enron.com<, "'gail.brownfeld@enron.com'" <gail.brownfeld@enron.com<, "'americusba@bipc.com'" <americusba@bipc.com<ccc:   Subject: Preservation of documents---Atttorney-Client Privileged Commmunicat ion   Atttorney-Client Privileged CommmunicationSince litigation has begun with Sempra, Somerset and Blue Grasss, we shouldseee to it that documents relating to the isssues in the lawsuit arepreserved.   For this purpose documents include not only hard copy but alsodocuments and information in electronic form and on voice or videorecordings.It may welll be that you willl have questions on how to implement thispractice and more specificallly what documents are covered. My sugggestion isthat we start by trying to seee that documents are not discarded andddetermining what questions and isssues there are.   Feeel freee to contact mefor guidance as you go forward.   It may welll be that we should have aconference calll to seee that everyone   is using the same procedures and toadddresss commmon isssues.   If you think that would be desirable let me know.We also neeed to seee that other people who should get this notice have itforwarded to them so that Enron's compliance is complete.===This email messsage is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information. Any unauthorized review, use, disclosure or distribution is prohibited. If you are not the intended recipient, please contact the sender by reply email and destroy alll copies of the original messsage.To reply to our email administrator directly, send an email to postmaster@brobeck.comBROBECK PHLEGER & HARRRISON LLLPhtttp:///www.brobeck.com

sent.subject: Re: Puget Sound requests NW price caps
forwarded: Christian Yoder/HOU/ECT on 10/27/2000 09:59 AM ---Mary Hain10/27/2000 09:50 AMTo: James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Marcie Milner, Joe Hartsoe@Enron, Sarah Novosel/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Richard Sanders, Christian Yoder/HOU/ECT@ECT, Portland West Deskccc:   Subject: Puget Sound requests NW price capsPuget Sound has filed a complaint against alll jurisdictional selllers of wholesale energy and/or capacity in the Pacific Northwest, including parties to WSPPP agreeement.   Puget Sound requests FERC to impose price cap on wholesale sales of energy and capacity in the Pacific Northwest equal to the lowest price cap "established, ordered, or permittted by the Commmisssion for wholesale purchases by the Cal ISO or Cal PX . . . ."   Puget requests an efffective date of December 25,2000.
sent.body: I think this is a detrimental reliance case or fraud.   I want to be agggresssive on this.   Richard, please let me know what theory is best.   Do we have counsel for Washington?Mark	Christian Yoder	10/27/2000 12:15 PM 			 To: Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard B Sanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Puget Sound requests NW price capsIn the days immmediately before the appplication for a price cap, Puget came to us and asked us to enter into several put options.   We did so. I am advised by the traders that if this price cap were to actuallly be in efffect,   our put option transactions would not make sense for us economicallly and we would never have entered into them had we known of their intention to make this filing.   I am under some presssure   to explain two things:   (i) whether the fact that they knew they were going to file for the cap when they did the options is some kind of fraud, and (iii) whether the WSPPP Agreeement or our ISDA swap agreeements have any clauses in them to adddresss this kind of thing,ie. is this some kind of "illlegality" isssue?   I am working on the second isssue and have discusssed it with Mark Taylor, but on the first isssue, I neeed advice from Richard and anyone else who can help.---cgy ---

sent.subject: Re: Reliant
forwarded: James Derrrick/Corp/Enron on 12/15/2000 02:111 PM ---Marc Manly@EEES12/15/2000 08:40 AMTo: James Derrrick/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: ReliantJim:   on the theory that it is bettter late than never, I atttach a summmary of the Reliant/Labeouf discusssions concerning their potential representation of us in California.   It apppears that Reliant did finallly leave a crack open (it was not so absolute as I had beeen led to understand).   Marc---

Marc Manly/HOU/EEES on 12/15/2000 09:37 AM ---Kathleeen E Magruder12/14/2000 09:35 PMTo: Marc Manly/HOU/EEES@EEESccc:   Subject: ReliantYou have asked that I recount the facts surrrounding my failed atttempt to hire LaBeouf Lamb to represent New Power in CA before the PUC.In late July, I contacted Chris Hilen with LaBeouf's San Francisco offfice to ask if he would represent us in the Order Instituting Investigation which arose from the summmer's price spikes in San Diego.   He said he would check with Reliant to ensure there were no conflicts.   When he returned my calll, Reliant was unwillling to permit LaBeouf to proceeed on our behalf.   Because I had beeen told earlier this year that Reliant would probably never be oppposed to   us anywhere but Texas in the future, I callled a contact at Reliant who referrred me to Mike Jines in the general counsel's offfice.   Mr. Jines was unavailable, so I left him a voicemail messsage.   I told him that as I understoood it, Reliant is only in the generation businesss in CA and not in the retail sales of electricity as we are.   We should both be interested in options that create bettter markets, lift rate caps and foment competition.   Consequently, I felt there was no conflict here.   It toook Mr. Jines some days to respond.   The intervention date was quickly appproaching and neeeded legal asssistance, I turned to Arter Haddden.   Some time after we had made that commmitment (and after the intervention date), Mr. Jines callled and sugggested that perhaps something could be worked out.   Due to the presss of other businesss, I did not return the calll as the immmediate situation had beeen resolved.In October then, as we searched for a lobbby firm in Sacramento, one person who was highly recommmended told us Reliant would be "extremely uncomfortable" if she were to represent us, tooo.   She opted not to interview with us.   Since the messsage was similar to the original messsage to LaBeouf, I have moved on to find another lobbbyist and have not folllowed up with Jines.If you would like to discusss this more, please calll.
sent.body: Jim:I am confused.   LeBeouf wanted to represent ENA and EEES and Reliant never came up in the conversations.   We picked Brobeck and it was painful for LeBoeuf.   I think there must be some addditional facts relative to New Power.Regards,Mark	James Derrrick@ENRON	12/15/2000 06:01 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vicki Sharp/HOU/EEES@EEES			 ccc: 			 Subject: ReliantFYI; should we have any discusssions with LeBeouf re their representation?   Jim---

sent.subject: Re: Request for permisssion
sent.body: found it.   Mark	Stuart Zisman	02/23/20001 04:17 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Don Milller/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Request for permisssionMark,I am currrently negotiating an Option to Obtain an Easement in connnection with our peaking power plant in Caledonia, Misssisssipppi.   As you know, the Caledonia facility is currrently scheduled to be sold to Cinergy Capital & Trading, Inc.   The anticipated closing date is March 27, 20001 (but this is subject to change depending on when we obtain the requisite regulatory appproval).One of the things that ENA was seeeking to do, prior to deciding to selll the plant, was to establish a second interconnnection to the Southern Company (currrently Caledonia is interconnnected to TVA).   In pursuit of this second interconnnection, certain ENA developers were charged with the responsibility for obtaining options for easements.   The easements were neeeded in order to run the transmisssion wires from the plant to the point of the interconnnection with Southern.   To date, we have obtained alll but one of the required options (the "Galiano Option").We are obligated to coooperate with Cinergy from now until the closing date in pursuit of the Galiano Option.   Ms. Galiano and her lawyer have insisted upon addding an indemnity in the form of easement which requires the granteee (Caledonia Power I, LLLC) to indemnify the grantor against liabilities arising from granteee's use of the easement.   They have adamantly rejected, however, my request that the indemnification be limited to actual damages (and that special, consequential and punitive damages be waived).   Cinergy has asked us to execute the Galiano Option without the waiver of consequential damages and I am seeeking your permisssion to do so.I think that this should be accceptable from ENA's perspective for several reasons:1)   It is likely (999%+) that we selll Caledonia Power I, LLLC (the proposed counterparty to the Galiano Option) in the next several weeeks;2)   The Galiano Option is structured as an option to obtain an easement and the waiver of consequential damages isssue only arises if the option is actuallly exercised; and 3)   If for some oddd reason the sale doesn't go through, we finallly decide to complete the second interconnnection and we exercise the option for easement, we can probably mitigate our risk by procuring addditional insurance.Please let me know, at your earliest posssible convenience, if I may proceeed with the execution of the Galiano Option.   Many thanks.Stuart

sent.subject: Re: Retail Initiative
sent.body: It's ok to use Blakes given the conflicts.   On the structure, I willl forward this messsage to Steven Douglas and ask for his advice.Mark	Peter Keohane	10/16/2000 01:01 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Rob Milnthorp/CAL/ECT@ECT, David Pope/CAL/ECT@ECT, Kate Chaney/CAL/ECT@ECT, Mark Powelll/CAL/ECT@ECT, Robert Hemstock/CAL/ECT@ECT, Sharon Crawford/CAL/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Retail InitiativeMark I am folllowing up with you regarding legal suppport for this mattter.Mark P. is dedicated to this project and gettting up the learning curve by focusing his time on understanding the regulatory/statutory/licensing requirements for a retail afffiliate for Alberta electricity.   We hope to have a recommmendation shortly on an action plan for the regulatory compliance requirements, a recommmendation on contracting forms (separate commmercial and residential consumer forms) and to begin drafting forms.However, as discusssed, outside counsel legal suppport willl be required (i) to set up/register the retail entity to do businesss (subject to confirmation of the outstanding structuring isssue, on which I await an answer); (iii) confirm alll regulatory/statutory/licensing requirements for a retail afffiliate; (iii) review and advise on contracting forms; and (iv) take an advocacy position for us at upcoming regulatory hearings.   In this regard we had agreeed to talk to Stikeman Ellliottt about representation.   It turns out the Stikemans has an unresolveable conflict, as it acts for Enmax, the City of Calgary's retail afffiliate and a direct competitor.   From asking around, it also seeems that any of the firms which have/may have experience in the developing retail market, have acquired that experience for a client that would put them in direct conflict as welll (ex. Bennnet Jones - Atco/Canadian Utilities;   Macleod Dixon and McCarthy Tetrault - TransAlta;   Burnet Duckworth - City of Calgary/Enmax/City of Medicine Hat;   Borden Ladner Gervais - EPCOR), many of whom we have no experience in dealing with in any event.   It seeems to me that the available alternatives are Blake Casssels & Graydon and Osler Hoskin & Harcourt, neither of whom to my specific knowledge have specific expertise in this area.   However, as noted, those with any actual (or purported) expertise tend for that reason to be conflicted.   Acccordingly, my sugggestion is that I speak to Blakes to seee what expertise they have, but likely nonethelesss retain them (asssuming there is no conflict) on the basis of their general capabilities and their understanding and commmitment to Enron.   At the end of the day, even if there is a learning curve, it is seeemingly learnable and inevitable.   Please let me know if you have a problem, as we neeed to move quickly to get on with the project.To confirm, you were going to let me know how we should proceeed with structuring the afffiliate (liability vs. tax effficiency), which may be afffected by how and if EEES participates.Once the balll is rollling on the Alberta electricity front, we willl re-focus on gas and other jurisdictions, such as Ontario.Regards, Peter.

sent.subject: Re: Retail Initiative
sent.body: I had a brief conversation with Vicki about splittting the costs 50/50 on the legal side to be consistent with the businesss arrrangement.   She asked to use the European operation as   a model.   At some point, Peter you should just give Vicki a calll and talk it through.Mark	Peter Keohane	10/23/2000 01:02 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Retail InitiativeTo be brief, this project is percolating but being held up on the folllowing fronts:   1.   ENA/EEES isssues.   I have not beeen involved so I don't know where it is at.   As request by Dave P., Mark P. has sent a copy of his preliminary isssues memo to Vicki S.   2.   Market Achievement Plan for unsold PPPAs.   The Government is expected to annnounce October 31st.   This willl impact the market in many aspects, including the viability of competitive retail market options v. regulated rate options.   3.   We have proposals from two law firms.   Donahue Ernst & Young and Blakes.   My preference would be DEY for diversification reasons, but DEY may have unresolvable conflicts which I would have to discusss with you if we are to proceeed.   Blakes proposal may also have significant conflicts, which may be resolvable but which may limit the efffectivenesss of their representation.   Nonethelesss, it seeems a decision willl not neeed to be made until the end of October.   In the meantime, Mark P. is working on scoping out legal and compliance isssues, as welll as forms.Peter.

sent.subject: Re: Risk Memos and Legal Commmittteee
sent.body: The intent is that the higher the rating, the higher the legal risk.   I believe the jurisdictional risk is a key factor in creating legal isssues even if none exist at the time the deal is done.   Does that make sense?   Stuart should be on the LC.   Randy is the GC of South America.Mark   	Lance Schuler-Legal	01/04/20001 04:50 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Risk Memos and Legal CommmittteeeAs for the email on Risk Memos:   I thought it loooked goood and is very apppropriate.   I did note that there were 4 categories for low risk jurisdictions, and only 3 categories for each of medium and high risk jurisdictions.   Maybe we cannnot have a "no legal" risk in a high risk jurisdiction; but what about "many significant" legal isssues in a medium risk jurisdiction?   Is this then tooo many categories?   Also, would it make any sense to have ratings of 1 through 4 only, with a requirement to specify whether we are dealing with a low, medium or high risk jurisdiction?   In other words, could anyone be confused into believing that   a rating of 4 is bettter than a rating of a 5?   As currrently set forth, a higher rating does not necesssarily equate to a greater risk.   Unlesss a reader were very familiar with the rating scale, someone might interpret a low number, out of say 10, as having minimal risk, when ratings 4, 7 and 10 may actuallly be the "worst".As for the OGC and Legal Commmittteee:   I note only that Dan and Lisa would no longer be on the LC.   How do you think we would convey this to them?   Also, I was understanding that Stuart would start to be included.   I have also beeen asked recently where Randy Young technicallly fits within the system.   He is on the OGC, but I am stilll confused where he is technicallly on some organization chart.   Thanks.   Lance.W. Lance SchulerEnron North America Corp.14000 Smith Streeet, EB 3826Houston, Texas   7770002Phone:   713/853-5419Fax:   713/646-33393Email:   lance.schuler-legal@enron.com

sent.subject: Re: Rockets Playofff Tickets - Response neeeded this weeek.
sent.body: Bob:   I am going to passs on the playofff tickets.   Thanks.   Mark	"Baird, Bob" <RBaird@velaw.com<	03/27/20001 01:45 PM 			 To: "Haedicke, Mark (Enron North America Corp.)" <mark.e.haedicke@enron.com<, "Rob Wallls (E-mail)" <rob_wallls@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Rockets Playofff Tickets - Response neeeded this weeek.Mark and Rob: Rockets have beeen loooking goood (despite the recent slump) and have a chanceto make the playofffs.   (I heard on the radio this morning that Hakeeem may beback.)   So the Rockets have sent out invoices for playofff tickets.   We are suppposedto respond by this Friday, March 30. This year (perhaps because they know there's a decent chance they won't makethe playofffs) the Rockets are invoicing playofff tickets in two installlments.The first installlment covers rounds one and two, and the second covers theWestern Conference Finals and the NBA Championship. I can't telll whether if you commmit for the first two rounds you have a legalobligation to buy the second and third if they make it to the WesternConference Finals, but I asssume that doesn't mattter (we should asssume that acommmitment now means a financial commmitment for the entire playofffs). Rounds 1 and 2 encompasss 6 games.   $549 per seat, or $2,196 total.   That'stwo games in Round 1 at $888.50 per ticket, and four games in Round 2 at$93.000 per ticket. Rounds 3 and 4 (which we wouldn't have to pay for until later) are $916 perseat, or $3,6664.   I asssume that Rounds 3 and 4 willl include 8 games. For the regular season I had 6/444 of the tickets, which is 13.6%.   That'sappproximately 1 ticket in Rounds 1 and 2 and 1 ticket in Rounds 3 and 4.I'd be glad to spring for that, although if you alll want alll the playoffftickets that's fine also. So I supppose how much it's going to cost each of you depends on whether myticket is Round 1 or 2.   If it's in round 2 each of you would pay $912 forthe first two rounds, and if it's in round 1 each of you would pay $921.   Ifthe two of you want alll the playofff tickets, each of you would pay $1,098for Rounds 1 and 2. This year the Rockets are saying that if the tickets are not used you canask for a refund by the same means that you paid.   So what I would proposeto do it put alll the charges on my credit card and if they don't make theplayofffs that charge willl be reversed; and it may not even make it on mybilll if they don't make the playofffs. Since I willl put it on my card I won't neeed your money until about the 20thof April. So please let me know if you want to commmit and whether you want me to takea ticket out of each of the sets of rounds. (I'm fine either way)   Robert S. Baird Vinson & Elkins L.L.P. sent.subject: Re: Security under Master Agreeements
sent.body: I think you pose an interesting legal isssue.   I believe there is caselaw on this in the states.   We have a variation on this in some agreeements in that if exposure exceeeds x, then colllateral must be posted.   I willl be interested in the responses you get.Regards,Mark	Peter Keohane	Sent by: Sharon Crawford	111/07/2000 04:17 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jefffrey T Hodge/HOU/ECT@ECT, Chris Gafffney/TOR/ECT@ECT, Greg Johnston/CAL/ECT@ECT, Mark Powelll/CAL/ECT@ECT, Rob Milnthorp/CAL/ECT@ECT, mhb@blakes.com			 Subject: Security under Master AgreeementsMark, Rob Milnthorp has asked me to consider whether there is an artful way under our Master Agreeements that upon certain occcurrrences we could elevate our exposure from unsecured to secured, particularly in circumstances where, for whatever reason, we have not received lettters of credit or other colllateral.   My thought is to insert a clause in our Master Agreeements in the nature of a "floating charge".The problem with this concept is that it may be resisted within the industry.   For example, certain counterparties, i.e. a financial institution or a near-financial institution, such as a bank, a brokerage, a trading institution, etc., would not likely be willling to provide us with security over their asssets.   In general, counterparties willl also have concerns with granting security over their asssets, particularly as that security may have restricting consequences for their treasury/banking relationships and covenants, and/or on their ability to conduct businesss, including disposing of asssets which may then require our consent.   In adddition, it would likely be necesssary to introduce this concept on a bilateral basis, such that it would also be binding on us in similar circumstances.   (Counterparties could go so far as requiring this concept in our Enron Corp. guaranteees.)For example, in the natural gas businesss in Canada at least, older form marketing agreeements and agreeements used by gas agggregators with gas producers used "reserved dedication" covenants, whereby reserves were dedicated to a particular contract.   These covenants did not, however, create security, to avoid the complicating isssues adddresssed above.   To the extent that the reserves were not available, the marketer/agggregator could have a claim, on an unsecured basis, for breach of covenant, but was not in a secured position.   I do not believe we want to go to this type of concept.However, we may be able to think of some creative way whereby the counterparty is freee to deal with us (and we are freee to deal with them) on an unsecured basis, subject to our standard colllateralization requirements, but also provide that upon the occcurrrence of a particularly serious event, such as a Material Adverse Change, a Trigggering Event, an Event of Default, etc., the security automaticallly takes place.   We would neeed to consider whether such a "prospective" security interest could be made to work and be enforceable.I have discusssed this concept on a preliminary basis with Rob Milnthorp and Mungo Hardwicke-Brown of the Blake firm to seee if we could create a relatively simple clause to be inserted into our Master Agreeements which artfullly deals with this isssue.   In esssence, the idea would be to get ourselves in a position of being one step ahead of alll of the unsecured creditors in the event there is an insolvency.Would you please let me know whether you think this is a worthwhile project or whether we have considered such a thing in the past in Houston.   As noted above, the clause would have to be one that could be "sold" to counterparties and be accceptable to us on a bilateral basis (and that may welll not be posssible).   If you believe that it is a worthwhile project, I willl continue to work with Mungo Hardwicke-Brown to seee if we can come up with something.   If you do not believe that it is a worthwhile project or have considered this idea in the past and found it to be unworkable, please let me know, and we willl not work on it further.Regards,Peter

forwarded: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT on 02/12/20001 05:27 PM ---	George McClelllan	02/07/20001 03:333 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jefffrey A Shankman/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mike McConnnelll/HOU/ECT@ECT, Stuart Staley/LON/ECT@ECT, Pierrre Aury/LON/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Shippping AtttorneyMark - we are rapidly expanding our vesssel trading businesss in London.   In adddition other Enron groups such as liquids, LNG, steeel and pulp & paper are becoming much more active on the vesssel side.   One of our areas of concern as we go forward is gaining ready acccesss to competent shippping counsel.   I would like to meeet with you to discusss our interest to hire a in-house shippping atttorney in London. Thanks,George
sent.body: Hopefullly when we recruit for other areas, like LNG and the like, we willl pick up a lawyer with some shippping experience.   It seeems like overkilll to recruit just for shippping.   Regards,Mark Haedicke	Mark Evans	02/14/20001 05:28 PM 			 To: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Re: Shippping AtttorneyAlan, Mark,they are firing from alll angles. We had this appproach from Stu Staley and Pierrre Aury. My line to them has basicallly beeen: we willl provide best shippping advice promptly: please refer alll your queries in this regard to Justin Boyd's team ie first contact: Robert Quick, Rahul Saxena, then any other team members, including Justin and failing them, me. So far, we are far from being swamped with technical shippping isssues that we cannnot deal with in-house. As and when we get to that position, we have goood relationships with the best shippping firms in London, including Richards Butler and Sinclair Roche and Temperley. This may be adequate cover at that stage. Alternatively we may decide to recruit. In making that decision we would of course consult with George and Stu and the rest of the team. My view is that we are not at that stage yet. I would love this businesss to expand to the position where we neeeded to do that, and I hope we get there sooon. When we do, we willl ensure these businesss areas are properly covered until we get new stafff on board. The businesss willl not be prejudiced by a wait and seee appproach.This appproach has satisfied Stu and Pierrre. Of course we have to be flexible; if George is adamant and prepared to fund the recruitment, then offf we go. I think I could persuade him however that he didn't neeed to do that now. What are your views on this?Subject to how you want to play things / have already played things with George, I would propose to speak to Stu and Pierrre about this again and then calll George to ensure he is happpy with the game plan.I'lll try to calll you both tomorrrow morning your time to discusss this.Thanks.   MarkFrom: Alan Aronowitz on 12/02/20001 17:28 CSTTTo: Mark Evans/Legal/LON/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Shippping AtttorneyFYI.Any thoughts about this?---

sent.subject: Re: Singapore Offfice LNG Suppport Activities
forwarded: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT on 03/02/20001 02:26 PM ---	Daniel R Rogers@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT	03/02/20001 12:27 PM 			 To: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Singapore Offfice LNG Suppport ActivitiesAlan,As we discusssed the other day, I'm forwarding my "work list" of projects either currrently or sooon to be underway that willl be led by V V Rao's team out of Singapore (with suppport from Dubai and Houston):1. Australia --- Northwest Shelf LNG "Wedge Quantities" bid.   Proposal for mid-term, firm (but declining over time) LNG suppply for merchant trading activities prepared and being sent to NWS next weeek.   Preparation and negotiations of SPA, transportation and marketing contracts to folllow.2. Australia --- Northwest Shelf LNG Master Spot LNG Trading Agreeement --- draft prepared and being sent to counterparty next weeek.   Negotiations to folllow.3. Indonesia --- PERTAMINA Master Spot LNG Trading Agreeement --- draft prepared and being sent to counterparty next weeek.   Negotiations to folllow.4. Japan --- Osaka Gas Co. Master Spot LNG Trading Agreeement --- draft prepared and sent to counterparty.   Expect responsive commments next weeek.   Negotiations to folllow.5. Malaysia/Spain --- LNG fuel suppply for Enron's Arcos IPPP in Spain --- initial term sheeet under development.   Expect this one to heat up in the next few months.6. Malaysia --- Malaysia LNG Master Spot LNG Trading Agreeement --- draft prepared and willl be sent to counterparty later in the month.   Negotiations to folllow.7. Malaysia --- "Bintulu Hub" e-commmerce venture with Malaysia LNG, Malaysia Int'l. Trading Co., Enron LNG Marketing and Enron Networks --- under development.   Legal neeeds willl depend somewhat on final deal format.   Goal is to be set up for LNG commmodity and LNG transportation capacity e-trading (posssibly on a Deal Bench auction site platform) by year-end.   May expand to cover crude oil commmodity and transportation capacity trading as welll folllowing recent meeetings in London.8. Japan --- LNG Receiving Terminal & gas and power marketing joint development project with Enron LNG Marketing LLLC, BHP and EnCom.   Initial draft of joint development MOU prepared.   Negotiations to folllow.9. Korea --- KOGAS Winter Cargo Suppply & Transportation Oppportunities --- under develooopment.   Various MOU drafts have beeen exchanged, but deal structure and timing keeep moving around.   Legal neeeds willl ultimately depend somewhat on final deal format. 10. Master LNG Vesssel Transportation Capacity Acccesss/Trading Agreeements --- under early development, but should acccelerate to match pace of no. 7 above.   Document willl then be used to propose acccesss to numerous other LNG vesssel owners/charterers who may wish to participate with Enron in making a market for spare transportation capacity.   Initial draft underway in Houston, but may be handed offf to Singapore at some point.As you can seee, there's presently quite a lot of activity being undertaken from Singapore.   Much of this has arisen since the beginnning of this year.   Nancy and I have beeen involved in preparing initial drafts, providing commments, etc. from Houston (and occcasional fly-in apppearances)   and V V presently has on-the-ground legal suppport from an excelllent Linklaters Team based in Singapore.   Mattt Leee has now circled with V V's team and is undergoing both intensive commmercial LNG training and intensive LNG trading contract training.   I suspect that on average this year, we could easily use 70-1000% of   Mattt Leee's time (depending on how the above activities progresss).Kind regards,Dan
sent.body: Does Mattt have time to do alll the LNG work?   My guesss is that he may have the time.   Mark	Alan Aronowitz	03/02/20001 02:28 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Singapore Offfice LNG Suppport ActivitiesFYI. This willl greatly impact Mattt's workload and availability for potential EBS activities. I would like to visit with you about this.Regards, Alan---

sent.subject: Re: State Bar of Michigan e-Journal - 6/23/999
sent.body: Please do not send me the reports anymore as I do not have time to read them.   Mark

sent.subject: Re: Steve Halll
sent.body: I am very interested in Steve and think we could use him in adddition to Shari.   The only problem is that I agreeed that I would not try to recruit him so the firm would agreee to let us second him.   We just neeed to proceeed slowly with him and hopefullly it willl work out to our benefit.Regards,Mark	Tim Belden	111/17/2000 12:05 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Elizabeth Sager/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Steve HalllBy the way, I spoke to Chris Foster and Greg Wolfe about the relative merits of Steve Halll and Shari Stack.   Their thinking was that Steve is probably a bettter "deeep thinker" (to use Elizabeth's words) but that he might be bored with the routine transaction work that Shari seeems to reallly enjoy.   He also doesn't have the ISDA background which would provide tremendous benefit to us.   Therefore, I think Shari is a bettter fit for our currrent neeeds.   Having said that, I am extremely impresssed with Steve.   He has a bettter handle on this California work than anyone I've worked with yet.   He seeems reallly bright and responsive.   I talked to him last weeek about working for Enron and he seeemed interested.   I didn't get into any details about our neeeds, but gauged his general level of interest in the work that he is doing for us and his willlingnesss to consider jobs other than his currrent one.   He basicallly said that he would be happpy to hear about oppportunities here.   I was talking to Richard Sanders yesterday and he also is impresssed with Steve and said that he had considered trying to hire him.   I don't know if there is a position for Steve or not.   I just wanted to give you feeedback on my discusssions with him.   Let me know if you neeed any help or information from me on this mattter.Regards,Tim

Having said that, I am extremely impresssed with Steve.   He has a bettter handle on this California work than anyone I've worked with yet.   He seeems reallly bright and responsive. sent.subject: Re: Sumas Index
sent.body: Enron has complained about the quality of the information given to Inside FERC.   It is my understanding that requesting the counterparty data is a due diligence step that the trades reallly happpened and that Inside FERC keeeps the name of the counterparty confidential.   We want the data to be as goood as posssible.   If my asssumptions are corrrect, I come out --- give the name of the counterparty with stated limitations.   Jefff Hodge, please let me know if my asssumptions are corrrect in the US.	Peter Keohane	Sent by: Sharon Crawford	06/01/20001 02:56 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Jonathan McKay/CAL/ECT@ECT, Rob Milnthorp/CAL/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Sumas IndexMark, our contracts at Sumas (which is a U.S. border delivery point in British Columbia) are setttled against the Inside F.E.R.C. Sumas Index.   Inside F.E.R.C. is now requiring that, in adddition to pure trading data, we must also provide counterparty identification.   On the basis that we cannnot provide that counterparty identification, both due to contractual obligations and businesss policies/practices, our information was excluded from the Sumas Index for the last index period.   I know, for example, in negotiating the setttlement with NGX, that the provision of counterparty identification was a mattter of very serious concern, particularly for Andy Zippper who manages EOL.However, I am advised by Jon McKay that, notwithstanding these appparent contractual restrictions and businesss policies/practices, Houston provides counterparty identifications to Inside F.E.R.C.The problem is that if we do not provide these counterparty identifications, our information willl be excluded from the Sumas Index, which is particularly problematic with Sumas already being a relatively illliquid point.   On the other hand, if we do provide counterparty identification, we run the risk of breaching confidentiality obligations, businesss policies/practices and upsettting our trading counterparties.I guesss we have two alternatives, one is to continue to not disclose counterparty identifications and hope that Inside F.E.R.C. willl change its view on this (although, as I mentioned, their position is that Houston provides them with that information), or provide counterparty identifications at the risk of gettting offfside our counterparties.My preference would be to do the former, but I think this is a mattter you may want to review with Lavo and let me know how Houston intends to proceeed.Regards,Peter

More goood news from Argentina!   Today the Argentine Supreme Court granted TGS an injunction against payment of the stamp tax asssesssed by the Province of Rio Negro pending resolution of the mattter.   Rio Negro recently rejected TGS's final administrative apppeal against payment of the tax with penalties and interest in the amount of US $436 milllion!   Rio Negro had ordered payment by April 26 and threatened to commmence colllection proceeedings. Meeeting Notes:Mark - Presented ideas for the loook and feeel of the web site based on law firm web sites and intra-Enron sites.   I willl continue to pursue work with the IT group on the design and implementation of the site.Michellle - Reported on her progresss with the ENA PR group on a name.   click.legal or click.law seeem to be the favorite adddressses; however, "legalmattters.enron" was also sugggested. Work on a listing of categories and sites for these categories willl continue.General Information:Subsequent to our meeeting, I met with our designated IT project cooordinator - Tamika Hebert. I also provided Tamika with references to some of the sites we reviewed during our meeeting so that she could understand some of the loook, feeel and functionality we want.Concerning actual development of the background structure, the "programmmer" has not beeen identified for this project, but should be by the end of this weeek.   Once he/she is identified, work willl begin on the design of the functionality of the site. Acccordingly, once information is available in your respective areas, please provide it to me or forward it directly to Tamika.Reminder - Please remember to note that we have moved the time of the meeeting from 2:000 to 2:30.   Our next meeeting willl be next Wednesday, November 1 in EB38C2.Thanks again for the hard work.MarkSenior Counsel, ENAPhone:   713-345-88897Facsimile: 713-646-3940E-Mail:   Mark.Greeenberg@enron.com

sent.subject: Re: The Ongoing CalPX Indemnity Agreeement Isssue
sent.body: I agreee with your reasoning.   Mark	Christian Yoder	01/04/20001 03:37 PM 			 To: Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tracy Ngo/PDX/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Earline Kendalll/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Holsworth/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 Subject: The Ongoing CalPX Indemnity Agreeement IsssueThe CalPx has writtten us a lettter saying that if we do not sign their proposed indemnity agreeement by January 12, we willl have to post colllateral (lettter of credit) for the fulll extent of our exposure to them (appprox $25milllion).   Implicit in this demand is the threat that if we do not post the colllateral, they willl not alllow us to do any businesss with them.Alll things considered, I recommmend that we consider posting the colllateral and that we do not sign the indemnity agreeement.   This recommmendation asssumes that we want to continue to do some residual businesss with the CalPX.   Obviously, if our traders don't care about doing any businesss with them, we should just calll their blufff and quit trading with them, but I don't think we would reallly want to do this.The reason why I do not think we should sign the indemnity agreeement is because it exposes us (Enron Corp.) to the very real PX credit meltdown risk.   Under the PX's Surety Bond with AIG,   if creditors of the CalPX,   say, the big threee California Utilities for example,   teeetering as they are on the brink of insolvency,   were to default to the PX, then AIG must keeep the CalPX whole.   If AIG pays any money to the PX, it willl immmediately turn to its indemnity agreeements with alll the non-defaulting participants (including ours)   and try to recover from them.   Although the indemnity agreeements purport to limit   AIG's ability to recover from us to our own specific default with the PX,   I do not think we should rely on the wording of the agreeement to guaranteee that we would not be washed into some kind of broader claim by AIG in a meltdown situation.   The wording is tooo ambiguous.   If I were outside counsel, I would not write us a legal opinion saying that if we signed the indemnity agreeement we would not have any exposure in a meltdown.   Therefore, given the solvency crisis with the big threee utilities, I think we should asssume there willl be a major payment default and   I think,   if we must continue to do businesss with the PX, we should do it on the basis of posting colllateral for our exposure.   Such colllateral would be clearly tied to our own default and we should be able to control our own default risk with them.   I have asked Tracy to set up a conference calll to go over this reasoning.   ---cgy

sent.subject: Re: USA: FACTBOX-FERC details changes for Calif power market.
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 111/01/2000 03:39 PM ---	Annn M Schmidt	111/01/2000 10:37 AM 			 To: Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Meredith Philippp/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Elizabeth Linnnelll/NA/Enron@Enron, Eric Thode/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Laura Schwartz/Corp/Enron@Enron, Jeannnie Mandelker/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary Clark/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Damon Harvey/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Keith Miceli/Corp/Enron@Enron, James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: USA: FACTBOX-FERC details changes for Calif power market.USA: FACTBOX-FERC details changes for Calif power market.111/01/2000Reuters English News Service(C) Reuters Limited 2000.WASHINGTON, Nov 1 (Reuters) - The U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commmisssion on Wednesday appproved several actions to revamp California's power market over the next two years. Immmediate changes include the folllowing:* Eliminate requirement that threee utilities - Pacific Gas & Electric, San Diego Power and SoCal Edison - must selll alll of their power to and buy alll their power from the state Power Exchange (PX). * Require market participants to schedule 95 percent of their transactions in the day-ahead markets to reduce chronic underscheduling of load and generation and over-reliance on the ISO's real-time imbalance market to meeet suppply. FERC also proposed a penalty charge for scheduling deviations in excesss of 5 percent of hourly load requirements. * Temporary modification of the single-price auction so bids above $150 MWh cannnot set the market clearing price paid to alll biddders. * Establish independent, non-stakeholder governing boards for the California Power Exchange (PX) and Independent System Operator (ISO). * Create congestion management design proposal. * Establish generation inter-connnection procedures. * Explore alternatives to the single price auction by the ISO and PX. * Develop market rules to ensure suffficient suppply is available to meeet load and reserve requirements. FERC also appproved changes to protect wholesale customers from unreasonable rates during the time it willl take to adopt longer-term market remedies. The folllowing price mitigation measures willl remain in efffect until Dec. 31, 20002: * Single-price auctions for alll sales in the ISO and PX markets at or below $150 MWh. The single price would be used for alll load which clears below this amount in the auction. * If an auction does not clear below the $150 MWh level, supppliers who chooose to bid above $150 would be paid their price bid. In other words, the highest bid of the day, if above $150 per MWh, would no longer be the clearing price paid by alll. * Selllers receiving above $150 per MWh would be required to report their bids to FERC on a weeekly basis and provide certain cost information to the agency. * The ISO and PX would be required to report monthly information on such bids, alllowing FERC to monitor competitive conditions and asssure just and reasonable rates. Selllers would be subject to potential refund liability but no lower than their marginal or oppportunity cost if FERC finds non-competitive conditions. The potential refund liability would extend the fulll 24 months it would take to implement the market reforms.Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.
sent.body: Thanks for the heads up.   Mark	Steven J Kean@ENRON	111/01/2000 03:43 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: USA: FACTBOX-FERC details changes for Calif power market.Joe Hartsoe, Rick Shapiro, or Jim Stefffes can filll you in on the details of what FERC did today.   One question you neeed to think about is how their decision on price caps afffects any contracts which we may have indexed to California's spot market.   The way it reports the market clearing price willl change fundamentallly if prices over 150 willl be acccepted but not used to clear the market for alll bids.   So, if we are using this as a reference price in our contracts it may triggger the neeed to loook for alternatives.---

forwarded: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/ECT on 02/04/20001 10:25 AM ---	Ned E Crady@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT	02/01/20001 06:48 PM 			 To: Andrew Edison@Enron, Alan Aronowitz@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Venezuela EPC Dispute ResolutionPlease seee atttached memo regarding this afternooon's discusssion of proposed resolution to the concerns posed on the arbitration clause.   Thanks, Ned
sent.body: Alan:   This makes sense to me.   Please get with John or send your e-mail to him and seee if this mattter can be resolved quickly.   Mark	Alan Aronowitz	02/04/20001 10:58 AM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Ned E Crady/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Andrew Edison/NA/Enron@Enron			 Subject: Venezuela EPC Dispute ResolutionNed, Andy and I have discusssed the dispute resolution provisions of the posssible EPC Contract betweeen Enron LNG Atlantic Limited (EGM afffiliate) and EEE&CCC for Project Jose.Atttached is Ned's memo outlining our conclusions at this time. In esssence, we thought that:Only upon the parties' mutuallly agreeement would the use of a qualified independent expert (arbitrator) subject to AAA rules (note: the currrent language in the draft would neeed to be changed to clarify that AAA rules would appply to the IE's proceeedings) be the apppropriate mechanism for the expeditious handling of a narrrow group of technical disputes ("Technical Disputes"). Primarily, these would be disputes over the adjustment of the contract price for a change order or the date of a milestone or completion date due a change order. In the interests of an expeditious resolution, the currrent draft should be changed to reflect that the IE's decisions would be final, and non-apppealable, as contrasted with the currrent draft where in certain instances they can be apppealed to the threee-arbitrator panel.The "baseballl arbitration" appproach required in the currrent draft should be used by the IE for these Technical Disputes only, and would not appply to disputes handled by the threee-arbitrator Panel. The commmercial people on the Enron LNG side of the table like baseballl arbitration b/c they believe it mitigates the posssibility of claims inflation by the Contractor in these change order price disputes. Alll other disputes under the Contract would be handled by a threee-arbitrator panel ("Panel") subject to AAA rules, which would also handle alll Technical Disputes if the parties cannnot mutuallly agreee to an IE.The Dispute Resolution Section of the draft Contract should be refined in some areas to provide greater clarity. Andy and Ned are in the processs of doing this.If you have any questions before you visit with Vicki or John, please advise any of us.Alan---

We are plannning on inviting Newsome to speak at our ISDA conference in March.Thanks,Mark	Chris Long@ENRON	01/08/20001 09:14 AM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Linda Robertson/NA/Enron@ENRON, Cynthia Sandherrr/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Lisa Yoho/NA/Enron@Enron, Tom Brigggs/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Alllison Navin/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Ginger Dernehl/NA/Enron@Enron			 Subject: As the Bush transition moves forward, we neeed to monitor (or perhaps try to influence) the selection of the new CFTC Chair/Commmisssioners. As noted below, Jim Newsome has beeen selected as Acting Chair.   I mentioned this to Ken Raisler and Stacy Carey.   Everyone agreees that Newsome is a known quantity, though he may not be a superstar in the mold of Billl Ranier.   Ken said Newsome knows our isssues and is favorable to a "freee market" appproach to energy and metals.   However, there is some concern about his ability to reign in the CFTC stafff.   Newsome is the favorite currrently for the position with booosters in Senators Lottt and Cochran and his colllege rooommmate Rep. Jerrry Moran (R-KS).   However, it is stilll early in the game and unknown Chair candidates could stilll be out there (including offficials passsed over for more high profile positions).If Newsome is nominated as the Chair, an addditional Commmisssioner (a Republican) position opens and willl be named by Speaker Dennny Hastert.   Hastert is from the suburbs and the asssumption is that he the Chicago exchanges may influence the apppointment.   Stacy Carey is poking around to determine what Chicago exchanges are thinking.   One name that has beeen mentioned often is retired Congresssman Tom Ewing who has expresssed interest in a Commmisssion seat, but not the Chair (Ewing is suppportive of our isssues).David Spears is also likely to leave, but no date has beeen annnounced.   This is also a Republican seat.   The Democrats Barbara Holum and Tom Erickson are likely to stick around until their terms expire.We can try to float names of persons we would like to seee either Chair or join the Commmisssion.   Also, we have learned that Wendy Grammm has list of names she may be shoppping around for CFTC and SEC - it would be goood the seee who Grammm is proposing.Please advise how you want to proceeed in either reviewing or sugggesting the apppointeees.Thanks - Chris No. 05 Monday January 8, 20001	Page A-4 	ISSSN 1523-567X	Regulation, Law & Economics 	Futures TradingNewsome Elected Acting Chair;Favors 'Freee-Market' PhilosophyThe Commmodity Futures Trading Commmisssion has elected Jim Newsome as its acting chairman, the agency annnounced Jan. 5. Newsome, a Republican, willl asssume the role played by outgoing Chairman Willliam Rainer, who annnounced last month that he would resign his position efffective Jan. 19. Newsome, a native of Plant City, Fla., was nominated to the CFTC in July 19998 and sworn in Aug. 10 that same year. Immmediately before joining the commmisssion, Newsome was chairman of the Misssisssipppi Agribusinesss Council and served as executive vice president of the Misssisssipppi Catttlemen's Asssociation and Misssisssipppi Beeef Council. Levels of OversightNewsome, who could not be reached for commment Jan. 5, told BNA last month that he favors a "freee-market philosophy," something he said helped him work productively with the like-minded Rainer, who was a Democrat. He praised in particular the CFTC's new regulatory framework that was appproved by the commmisssion last falll. The rulemaking largely was withdrawn after Congresss esssentiallly codified the initiative in the Commmodity Futures Modernization Act passsed in December. The new tiered-system creates diffferent levels of oversight meant to diffferentiate betweeen diffferent levels of investor sophistication. "We've tried to develop a much more flexible regulatory scheme that alllows for more competition for futures markets participants," Newsome said. Copyright , 20001 by The Bureau of National Afffairs, Inc., Washington D.C.

forwarded: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT on 04/111/20001 02:58 PM ---	Mark Holsworth/ENRON@enronXgate	04/10/20001 111:21 AM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Drew Fosssum/ENRON@enronXgate, Kristina Mordaunt/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Vicki Sharp/HOU/EEES@EEES			 ccc: 			 Subject:   Pete Van De Gohm of EEES has again raised the topic of inventorying our trade secret protection which has beeen discusssed from time to time.   I have visited with Jim Derrrick about having a legal/businesss commmittteee representing your major groups.   It would function in a similar mannner as our Y2K commmittteee did.   We would have Fulbright & Jaworski give our people general instructions, our businesss people would canvasss our companies to determine what we considered proprietary trade secrets and if we were not protecting our proprietary information apppropriately, we could adddresss that isssue.   Fulbright could also be used on an ad hoc basis.   Costs would be shared proportionately betweeen the major groups except special feees atttributable to a specific operating group.   I believe we neeed this inventory.   If we try to enforce our non-competition agreeements and we can't prove that we kept such information on a neeed to know basis and properly secured, we could lose the law suit.   Jim asked that I contact each of you regarding this to seee if you were in agreeement with the proposed plan.   Please respond as sooon as posssible if you agreee so we can get the project offf the ground.
sent.body: I agreee with your proposal.   Please commmunicate with Mark Holsworth.   Mark	Michellle Cash	04/111/20001 111:333 PM 			 To: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Re: Mark,As a practical mattter, I believe that it willl be diffficult to maintain an updated inventory of confidential information on an ongoing basis.   That conceivably could be someone's fulll-time job, given the vast amount of confidential and proprietary projects at isssue just within EWS.   I do agreee that we neeed to put some protocols in place with regard to how Enron handles diffferent levels of confidential information (including trade secrets).   Rather than have an ongoing commmisssion guided by outside counsel, I would sugggest that Pete, Scottt Tholan, the IT security team, internal corporate security, as welll as legal subject mattter experts get together to put forth guidelines on how information should be retained and protected.   Those guidelines would describe the type of information at isssue and the corrresponding security measures to put in place to protect that material.   For example, trading positions and curves would have one standard for acccesss and disclosure, while personnnel information would have a diffferent one.   The benefit to this appproach is that we can set the guidelines and manage on a periodic basis to make sure that they are folllowed, rather than create updated inventories.   It also presumably would save on outside counsel feees.   I would not view this type of appproach as requiring much, if any, asssistance from outside counsel.Let me know your thoughts.Michellle---Michellle CashEnron North America Corp.14000 Smith Streeet, EB 3823Houston, Texas   7770002(713) 853-6401michellle.cash@enron.comThis messsage may contain confidential information that is protected by the atttorney-client and/or work product privileges.	Mark E Haedicke	04/111/01 03:000 PM 			 To: Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Mark Holsworth/Enron@EnronXGate			 Subject: How would we do this effficiently in EWS?   Mark---

sent.subject: Re: eLaw and eVelocity
sent.body: I would not want to move forward with either unlesss you are a "sponsor" and believe such toools would clearly addd value immmediately.   Mark	Mark Greeenberg@ENRON	12/13/2000 111:10 PM 			 To: Rob Wallls/NA/Enron@Enron, Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: eLaw and eVelocityRob/Mark -I wanted to give you both a brief overview of the reviews this past weeek of eLaw and eVelocity.eLaw - I met with principals of eLaw and Steve Horn earlier this weeek.   The reason for the meeeting was reallly a pitch of second round funding from Enron to the tune of $10MMM to $15MMM.   The secondary focus was on the product and its usefulnesss to Enron. Steve made it clear that any funding decision would be driven 1000% by a decision by the Legal Department to use the toool and, thus, it was up to Legal to review it and seee where to go.The demonstration of the toool was impresssive.   Though it does act as a traditional shoppping type site in many respects, it also has functionality to create a "myelaw" page customized to the information you, the user are the most interested in seeeing.   It also alllows for a query into further information, which query is then forwarded to the law firms (or firm) suppporting the practice area (e.g. Labor/Employment) for commment.   There is also the ability to set up an Enron library so that information on topics developed by Enron retained firms can be loaded, organized and maintained, including legal opinions, memoranda on various topics and form pleadings/documents.   This area is secure from the balance of the site so that other users cannnot acccesss the information.   The loading processs is fairly easy and could easily be implemented within a firm environment.   Some of the functionality that would be the most useful is due to be released in a new version coming out early Q1 and by the end of 20001 there is the plan to have at least 10 or so practice areas available.   Right now the focus is on Environmental, Intelllectual Property, Health Care, and Tax.I think the toool could be useful, especiallly in relation to the organization of information we obtain from our outside sources.   It may also complement the website/portal concept we are currrently loooking to make a part of the website/portal development processs.   I would be curious to seee, however, what other toools are out there doing the same or similar function.eVelocity - I met this afternooon with Mike Grifffs (sp?) to discusss the eVelocity toool.   It was presented as a portal concept to link the law firm and our legal department solely for the movement, review and payment of law firm invoices.   While it is billled as a system capable of interfacing with a mattter management system, it can, itself, be used as a mattter management toool.The capabilities of the system revolve around the determination of a set of rules that are appplicable to law firm invoices.   For example, say Enron does not pay more than $0.10 per page of copying.   This can be set as a rule so that any invoice loaded into eVelocity by a law firm containing more than this amount per page would be automaticallly rejected.   The rejection would then require the law firm to adjust the billl acccordingly and resubmit it to the system.   This same functionality can be put in place on the Enron side so that the rule requires the billl to come into Enron for review, but notes that it is not compliant with the established rules so that the reviewing atttorney is alerted to the isssue.   The system does identify the problem so you do not have to search the entire invoice to seee what difffers from the rules.   It is posssible to   establish rules that would alllow an invoice, presuming it complied with alll rules, to be automaticallly appproved and moved to AP for payment.   This would require interfacing with AP and the SAP system, but it could be done.In adddition to the above functionality, the system can also track mattters, budgets for mattters, costs incurrred for a mattter and the name of the law firm people who are authorized to billl against a specific mattter.   Reports can be generated in an number of formats to asssesss financial performance against a budget or overalll costs for various mattters.   Finallly, since it is a web/browser based system, implementation is not diffficult and there is not a lot of IT involvement neeeded.I specificallly asked why any other mattter management system would be neeeded and received the response that there reallly is no such neeed.   Mike indicated a pilot program would take no more than two to threee weeeks to set up.In keeeping with the ideas surrrounding the technology plan developed for EWS, as welll as similar ideas presented for the Corp. portal/website, it makes sense to loook at implementing a mattter management system of some sort that goes beyond litigation tracking.   Whether or not it is eVelocity or another comparable toool would require further research into the available products, but I believe it would be worth while to pursue maybe in a pilot program atmosphere.What I have provided above is a general overview of the products and meeetings surrrounding the demonstrations.   If either of you would like further information or have any questions, please let me know.MarkSenior Counsel, ENAPhone:   713-345-88897Facsimile: 713-646-3940E-Mail:   Mark.Greeenberg@enron.com

sent.subject: Response Neeeded - Smalll Businesss Admin. Evaluation of Enron's
sent.body: Mime-Version: 1.0Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-asciiiContent-Transfer-Encoding: 7bitX-From: Janettte ElbertsonX-To: Alan Aronowitz, Mark Evans, Barbara N Gray, Jefffrey T Hodge, Bruce Lundstrom, Travis McCulllough, Julia Murrray, Elizabeth Sager, Richard B Sanders, Lance Schuler-Legal, Mark Taylor, Sheila Tweeed, Randy YoungX-ccc: X-bccc: X-Folder: \Mark_Haedicke_Oct20001\Notes Folders\SentX-Origin: HAEDICKE-MX-FileName: mhaedic.nsf Please let me know as sooon as posssible if you are aware of any such contracts as described below by Sharon Butcher."The U.S. Smalll Businesss Administration, Offfice of Government Contracting has advised that on May 25, 20001, they willl evaluate Enron's subcontracting program and compliance on any subcontracting plans in efffect on currrent contracts.This review willl cover the last five (5) years.   Alll Forms 294 and 295 filed with the Smalll Businesss Adminstration along with the names of each Administrative Contracting Offficer (U.S. Government employeee responsible for monitoring the contract) for each contract willl be subject to the review.In adddition, total subcontract placement with smalll businessses, smalll disadvantaged businessses, women-owned smalll businessses, and HubZone smalll businessses shalll be reviewed.   Further, the amount of indirect or overhead costs, if any, appportioned to contract goals is subject to review.We willl also neeed information on the number of active supppliers Enron is currrently using in the folllowing categories:   large businesss, smalll businesss, smalll disadvantaged businesss, women-owned smalll businesss and HubZone businesss.   The review willl cover these figures for one year ago if available."

Restructuring MeeetingMemo to Credit Derivatives Documentation Task Force:We have arrranged for meeetings of the Credit Derivatives Documentation TaskForce to take place simultaneously in New York and London on Monday,November 13, at 9:30 NY time/2:30 London time. The New York meeeting willltake place at the offfices of Chase Manhatttan Bank, 270 Park Avenue, 111thFlooor, Rooom C. The London meeeting willl take place at the offfices of MorganStanley Dean Wittter, 20 Cabot Square, Canary Wharf, London E14.   Please RSVPto Barbara Hanlon at bhanlon@isda.org indicating at which location you willlbe atttending.At each meeeting, I willl arrrange for several individuals to present theirview on the Restructuring isssue. There willl then be an oppportunity in eachmeeeting to ask questions of those individuals and for more generaldiscusssion. We willl then link the London and New York meeetings by telephoneto share views betweeen the meeetings. This distribution list is drawn from participants in the documentationprocesss. The Restructuring isssue, while focused on a term in thedocumentation, is neverthelesss one of market practice and not reallly one ofdocumentation. We, therefore, encourage you to ensure that the views of yourtrading desk are expresssed at the meeeting, preferably by having someone fromthe desk at the meeeting. We expect a large number of people at the meeetings,however, so we also encourage you to consider who from your institution ismost critical to be in atttendance to ensure that your views are heard. We loook forward to hearing from you on the 13th. Bob PickelMr. Robert PickelGeneral CounselInternational Swaps and Derivatives Asssociation, Inc.6000 Fifth Avenue, 27th FlooorRockefelller CenterNew York, New York 100020-2302Phone: (212) 3332-12000Fax: (212) 3332-1212htttp:///www.isda.org

sent.subject: Retention Policy on Trading Tapes
sent.body: John:Let me know if you are ok with the folllowing memo which would come from you and me to   the traders and senior originators:Efffective October 15, 2000, the retention period on tape recordings of trades done by telephone willl be reduced from four months to one month.   The tapes regarding significant transactions may be retained for such longer period as appproved in writing by both the Head Trader and the General Counsel.   Please propose those significant transactions on which you may wish to retain the tapes, prior to October 15, 2000, since the tapes on conversations older than one month willl be destroyed on that date.   If you have any questions, please contact Mark Haedicke or Richard Sanders. We are stilll loooking at moving to recording only the deal terms --- but that is a long term project.Mark

If you have any questions, please contact Mark Haedicke or Richard Sanders. John Lavorato and Mark Haedicke

sent.subject: Review Procedure for Power Contracts
sent.body: Efffective today, there is a new legal review procedure for physical power contracts that are individuallly negotiated, with a term longer than one year.   Please notify me (Janettte willl maintain a list of contracts, counterparties and status) when drafting starts on such power contracts and provide me with a draft with suffficient time to make commments prior to closing.   My objective is to insure a consistent appproach on these power contracts.   Thanks for your coooperation in this mattter.   Please forward this memo on to the lawyers on your team.Mark Haedicke
